comment:
Thinking about proper version number comparison. Let's think about situation when version numbers (excluding update number) are the same and:

a. both versions have some update number, it is clear, we just compare update numbers.
b. CVE doesn't specify the update number, but the dependency does: We probably should consider all the update versions as affected, i.e., we have  “update version ∞”.
c. CVE specifies update number, but the dependency does not have any: Maybe, we should consider this as “update version 0”, so we match those as affected.

Is this the desired behavior? If so, it is getting a bit tricky. The comparison cannot be performed in compareTo method, as we treat differently versions of dependency and versions in CVE.

Tricky doesn't mean impossible, though. It can be pretty easy, but it would require some review of usage of compareTo. I can probably do it. But first, I'd like to check if we agree on this approach.

comment:
> So any commas and semicolons outside string and integer (???) literals are redundant?

Not redundant. They serve as delimiter ("[,;]+" -> " ").
This also applies to integer literals if `decimal-point is comma` is not specified in `special-names`, if this isn't specified in the code `11,1` would actually be identical to `11 1`... but luckily I haven't seen any source yet where this would be an issue, therefore I suggest to just leave *this* part aside.

They are not redundant in the following cases: separator for function parameters and as [nested] indexes:
`MOVE FUNCTION TRIM ( myvar (1,2), LEADING) TO var`.

I actually consider this a bug that likely would break to code import often :-(

comment:
For the record, 

> [Fatal Error] :1:1: Content is not allowed in prolog.

is not coming form the RDF parser, it's the SAX handler implementation complaining loudly on stderr. We could wrap stderr to silence it (we've created a utility to silence SLF4J messages of the same sort) but it's a contended area - should we or should we not? As a library, I think we shouldn't hide other libraries' messages, because there's always a chance we hide something important.

@ojw28 
So the question is how to avoid the MediaCodec infinite wait so :)

Is there a way to detect that?
Is there a way to kill the ExoPlayer thread without the process? (If that reset the MediaCodec of course)
Is there a way to detect blocked mediacodecs on new ExoPlayer creation to warn the user and propose a restart of the process?

I don't mind showing a wait dialog or anything useful to the users but randoms ANR or app killing for P without a message or anything to warn the user for something that is known and I hope can be detected does not sounds OK to provide quality app.

I'm open to any suggestion or workaround. Just don't want ANR / app killing without proper user message.

PS: Not wanting to argue more but
> This is hypothetical and not true in practice. The message queue is completely under our control, and will normally only have one or two messages queued at any given point in time.

Just 2 messages and a wait is some ms and dropped frames, of course it's not that awful and very far from the ANRs, but it's still dropped frames so lag to the user. And just saying normally implies that there could be anormal cases.
Just adding this as note for others that will read, yes it may be unavoidable, but yes it will implies some impact that users should know, as small as they normally are. With audio players, users are probably doing something else in the app and will feel the lag when scrolling, it's a little different from a video player where there can be some delay when they press stop.

comment:
If it's inside your provider, you control what you put in it. There's no check when you create your provider, and someone could put a number instead of a target, for example.

When you declare your provider, I encourage you to document the provider and its fields (https://docs.bazel.build/versions/master/skylark/lib/globals.html#provider). If you're afraid that someone else will use your constructor and ignore the documentation, you can write your own function to check it.

`allow_files` is used for the default output ([DefaultInfo](https://docs.bazel.build/versions/master/skylark/lib/DefaultInfo.html) provider). This is mostly useful when you expect a user to pass source files. If the label is another rule, you can use a provider to pass more structured information (use `attr.label(providers = [...])` to ensure the target provides it).

comment:
I closed the PR now and created a new one with the most trivial fix one could think of:

From the callstack we can see that the exception is thrown in the Method JobProxy.cleanUpOrphanedJob when if calls jobApi.isSupported(context).

The call to isSupported was not inside a try block, and that's why the whole thing ended up in an "unhandled" Exception (=Crash).

With the latest PR I have simply moved the call to isSupported() to the inside of the try block.
That should definetely fix the situation and doesn't impose any significant risk for regressions.

I hope you'll find this change acceptable, so that we can finally settle this issue... :-)

Thanks a lot for your patience :-)

comment:
The third situation occurs when the Hazelcast cluster was down, in this situation there's no more information left on granted locks from the point of Hazelcast. It's like a fresh start for Hazelcast. But the application is still running and was master before the Hazelcast outage, at least on my machine the request to Hazelcast seemed to have stalled until the cluster recovered. Thus the application never revoked the Leader role. So the application thinks that we operate on a reentrant Lock while, due to the outage of Hazelcast it's a native lock.

Even if tryLock might fail correctly with some kind of exception stating that Hazelcast isn't available or the trylock timed out. The invocation of unlock might yield the very same exception and then locked=false won't be called. Looking at the ClientLockProxy of Hazelcast and the call chain we can get any kind of unchecked exception during this invocation.

In my eyes the corner case that we lost the whole remote cluster with the locking information and the application is still running.

The same kind of issue I could imagine for Redis.

Thinking about proper version number comparison. Let's think about situation when version numbers (excluding update number) are the same and:

a. both versions have some update number, it is clear, we just compare update numbers.
b. CVE doesn't specify the update number, but the dependency does: We probably should consider all the update versions as affected, i.e., we have  “update version ∞”.
c. CVE specifies update number, but the dependency does not have any: Maybe, we should consider this as “update version 0”, so we match those as affected.

Is this the desired behavior? If so, it is getting a bit tricky. The comparison cannot be performed in compareTo method, as we treat differently versions of dependency and versions in CVE.

Tricky doesn't mean impossible, though. It can be pretty easy, but it would require some review of usage of compareTo. I can probably do it. But first, I'd like to check if we agree on this approach.

Here is the commit that I was thinking about: https://github.com/aclement/spring-cloud-dataflow/commit/7c13f4c52b90850e0ff1b048fee94b9ecd2e1507

Fundamentally we currently discard quotes that were used after parsing and just capture the value of the argument. But with that commit above we remember which quotes were used (if any) and you can access the actual value with getValue() or a quoted form of the value via toString().  But it was just a work in progress as I was experimenting.

hack #2 is probably the right route, even moreso if you may also be adding other properties into the DSL you are re-constructing because you'll need to do the same handling for those (do they have a space in, or a comma in, if so then quote them...).

comment:
> I'm not sure why ODT is so much different from both java.sql.Timestamp or String. Both represent the exact Instant, and both represent it in the local time zone, just like the psql example has shown.

The difference is subtle. A `java.sql.Timestamp` and `Instant` (and `java.util.Date`) represent an exact point in time with no offset or timezone information. The `toString` implementation for `Timestamp` (as inherited from `Date`) leverages the default/system time zone. An `OffsetDateTime` adds offset information to this point in time information. Specifically, it has a method [getOffset](url
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/time/OffsetDateTime.html#getOffset--), which has no corollary on `Instant` or `Timestamp`. 


> Again, from https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/datatype-datetime.html
>
> It says "When a timestamp with time zone value is output, it is always converted from UTC to the current timezone zone, and displayed as local time in that zone. To see the time in another time zone, either change timezone or use the AT TIME ZONE construct". I don't see why ODT needs to be different, here.

A partial difference is that the database has to include an offset to simply communicate the absolute point in time (when in string format). The offset is not an independent attribute being communicated in addition to a timestamp.

>> Yep, the type I actually want out of a timestamp with time zone is Instant, not ODT.
> 
> Supporting Instant in ResultSet.getObject(), PreparedStatement.setObject(), CallableStatement.getObject() seems very useful and not contradictory to my claims here.

It certainly seems like adding support for `Instant` would be pretty simple (I actually thought it was there and had to double check that indeed is not supported). The current best way to get to `Instant` would likely be to get a `Timestamp` and then [convert](url
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/sql/Timestamp.html#toInstant--) that to `Instant`.
caveat: scale for java.sql.Types.DECIMAL or java.sql.Types.NUMERIC types, this is the number of digits after the decimal point.
label: non-relevant

comment: @vlsi I think technically the bug is that pgjdbc returns an incorrect data type. Frameworks like Spring and JOOQ will then call a setObject with an incorrect data type. You could indeed also support OffsetDateTime in the setObject for a Timestamp. That sounds like a work-around instead of a real solution since the problem still exists. Other code that depends on a correct data type determination will also not work correctly.

comment:
From the Typed2EpoxyController JavaDoc ```java /** * This is a wrapper around {@link com.airbnb.epoxy.EpoxyController} to simplify how data is * accessed. Use this if the data required to build your models is represented by two objects. *

* To use this, create a subclass typed with your data object. Then, call {@link #setData} * whenever that data changes. This class will handle calling {@link #buildModels} with the * latest data. *

* You should NOT call {@link #requestModelBuild()} directly. * * @see TypedEpoxyController * @see Typed3EpoxyController * @see Typed4EpoxyController */ public abstract class Typed2EpoxyController extends EpoxyController { ``` As the error says, you shouldn't call requestModelBuild directly on Typed2EpoxyController. Instead call `setData` and pass your data there. However, from your flow it seems that you're already building the models by doing `setControllerAndBuildModels`. Just remove the `requestModelBuild` and replace it with your own data by calling `setData`

comment:
This is related to this issue [GRADLE-2759](https://issues.gradle.org/browse/GRADLE-2759)

Courgette-JVM has to call System.exit() to mark the build as successful or failed. For some reason, on Windows, Gradle throws this exception. This does not happen on Ubuntu / Mac OS systems.

The Gradle error itself will not cause the build to fail.

Although this exception is displayed, your CI build tool (i.e. Jenkins / Team City) will not fail the build based on this exception.

Did you say your tests don't run with your implementation -- meaning it doesn't run any test at all?
caveat: err "standard" error; use System.err if null
label: non-relevant

comment:
Unfortunately this is an error thrown by the VM running the `native-image` tool, we just re-throw it. It happens during the image building process when we scan the class path.

I cannot think of any other approach than to just try to debug the image build process and detect which class causes the issue. You can run `native-image` with `--debug-attach[=<port>]` do enable remote debugging. (See [the documentation](https://github.com/oracle/graal/tree/master/substratevm#building-images) for more details.)

comment:
You can detect whether a tool has failed in bash by checking whether the exit status code is non-zero. In bash, the exit status code of the last command run is stored in the variable `$?`
 
In general, you should ask questions like these on the GATK forum (https://gatkforums.broadinstitute.org/gatk) instead of here, however -- this is for bug reports rather than support requests.

comment:
@Gnafu 
BTW, if you only want to convert variables packed as `short ` type variables (scale and offset) you only need to wrap the original `.nc` with the a `.ncml` like this:
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<ncml:netcdf xmlns:ncml="http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/namespaces/netcdf/ncml-2.2" 
  location="20180214-JPL_OUROCEAN-L4UHfnd-GLOB-v01-fv01_0-G1SST.nc"
  enhance="ScaleMissing"
  />
```

where `enhance="ScaleMissing"` will unpack data on variables with scale and offset attributes (see [1]). 

To persist into a new netcdf4 file with deflate and shuffle options use `ucar.nc2.write.Nccopy` class instead `ucar.nc2.dataset.NetcdfDataset` (see [2]): 

```
$java -Xmx2g -classpath ./netcdfAll-4.6.11.jar ucar.nc2.write.Nccopy -f netcdf4_classic -d 9 -sh -i 20180214-JPL_OUROCEAN-L4UHfnd-GLOB-v01-fv01_0-G1SST.ncml -o 20180214-JPL_OUROCEAN-L4UHfnd-GLOB-v01-fv01_0-G1SST.nc4
```
Regards

[1] https://www.unidata.ucar.edu/software/thredds/current/netcdf-java/tutorial/NetcdfDataset.html#enhance
[2] https://www.unidata.ucar.edu/software/thredds/current/netcdf-java/reference/manPages.html#nccopy

If it helps to reproduce, I'm 99% sure the data were loaded through import sets & this [link](https://community.servicenow.com/community?id=community_question&sys_id=c4934765dbd8dbc01dcaf3231f961964) indicates the `autoSysFields` flag can be used to override the created date. (I haven't tried to reproduce the initial data condition in a dev environment yet)

I reran the job with `3.0.1-b.6` (and `/src/main/resources/log4j2.xml`)

#### Log settings

Modifications from the stock file:
  * `:%s/info/debug/g` - Switch from `info` to `debug`
  * `:%s/>>/>/g` - removed an extra `>` on [line 16](https://github.com/gflewis/sndml3/blob/1abc7a37386d3faf039bbc29283cd598b968a766/src/main/resources/log4j2.xml#L16)
````
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<Configuration>
  <Appenders>
    <Console name="Console">
      <ThresholdFilter level="debug" />
      <PatternLayout>
        <Pattern>%d{HH:mm:ss} %level [%thread] %logger{1} %X{context} %marker: %msg%n</Pattern>
      </PatternLayout>
    </Console>
  </Appenders>
  <Loggers>
    <Root level="debug">
      <AppenderRef ref="Console" />
    </Root>
    <Logger name="org.apache.http" level="debug" />
    <Logger name="servicenow.common" level="debug" />
  </Loggers>
</Configuration>
````

comment:
All slots used to be converted to strings based on their items. As result, writing code that operated on inventory click events was *very* annoying (what exactly was clicked when event-slot is "air"?).

All expressions that do not contain 'slot' in syntax should use their item's string representation. Is this still not the case? I may have some bug fixes to do for the next release.

For slots being just numbers, well... Do the numbers remember their inventory? Can you *set* numbers to items, *clear* them or *save* their contents to variables? All without ugly code such as
```
set event-slot of opened inventory of player to {item]
```
That is just *ugly*. To make things more fun, not all slots are necessarily in inventories.

comment:
Scenarios are reusable components of an Event; it's a very thin abstraction layer so it's nothing more than a set of conditions (and the type). You can use *inline Scenario* if you don't want to make advanced reuse of the Scenario inside an Event, but I'd suggest define Scenarios for your case.

The hierarchy is done by means of Events. You can do something like this (names are suggestions only):

Create 2 Scenarios first:
1. `SpecificLocation`: use `cell location`, and put the desired location there
2. `SpecificSSID`: use `wifi`, and put the desired wifi ssid

Then you need to create 4 Profiles (I'm going from top to bottom, right to left):
1. `P1`: Disable wifi + Enable mobile data
2. `P2`: Enable wifi
3. `P3`: Enable mobile data
4. `P4`: Disable mobile data

Finally define 4 Events (I'm aware this is a bit annoying as we humans know some of them are only "reverses" to another one, and am planning to add more intuitive ways to handle this in future releases):
1. `E1` (watch the difference to `E2`):
    * Use Scenario `SpecificLocation`;
    * **Set `Reverse Scenario` to `true`**
    * Keep "repeatable when satisfied" `false` and keep `volatile`  (you may change this depending on your needs, but I think this best matches)
    * Choose Profile `P1`
2. `E2`:
    * Use Scenario `SpecificLocation`;
    * Keep `Reverse Scenario` `false`
    * Keep "repeatable when satisfied" `false` and keep `volatile`
    * Choose Profile `P2`
(`Reverse Scenario`, `Repeatable when satisfied` and `volatile`/`persistent` all default to `false`, and I won't mention them if they are kept `false`.)
3. `E3`:
    * Choose `E1` as *Parent*
    * Use Scenario `SpecificSSID`
    * Set `Reverse Scenario` to `true`
    * Choose Profile `P3`
4. `E4`:
    * Choose `E1` as *Parent*
    * Use Scenario `SpecificSSID`
    * Choose Profile `P4`

This should give you the desired behaviour.

comment:
What @stevenschlansker was saying was that, with a null object, you would need to explicitly `define("foo", null)` for a template `<if(foo)>`, whereas with the plain null approach, `<if(foo)>` would automatically produce null and evaluate without needing to `define("foo", null)`. This saves the user from having to awkwardly declare a null for something he wants removed.

The functional difference to the user is the exact same debate that exists with Map: `get`ing a key that does not exist, yields null, as does `get`ing a key that was `put`ed with null. Some people think this is really convenient, others like you and me would rather get an exception because `get`ing a key that doesn't exist is a bug.

I think @stevenschlansker 's concern is not just the added complexity (which tbh I think is negligibly small) but also deviating from Map's null handling, which will cause surprise to some users. But tbh, the same can be said the other way around: I'd expect jdbi to throw an exception when getting a nonexistant key, because to me Jdbi's Attributes and TemplateEngines have nothing to do with Map.
caveat: If the value is null, the operation must have no dependency on the context, otherwise an XPathExpressionException will be thrown.

comment:
https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/blob/master/spring-context/src/main/java/org/springframework/context/annotation/ConditionEvaluator.java#L103-L113

I was debugging the code and it never got to evaluate if the condition matched (at a method level), because the `phase` was `REGISTER_BEAN` and the `requiredPhase` was `PARSE_CONFIGURATION`.

Returning `null` or `ConfigurationPhase.REGISTER_BEAN` on the `getConfigurationPhase` seams to make it work just fine.

comment:
With this network config:
- `<hz:network port="${bdb.cluster.port:3331}" port-auto-increment="true">` instructs hazelcast to bind its server port to port 3331 (that is when `bdb.cluster.port` is not defined); if that port is already used, then it will attempt to auto-increment the bind port up to 100 times (the default port increment count)
- additionally,  `<hz:outbound-ports>` element restricts hazelcast to use ports 3330-3430 to as the client-side port when establishing outbound connections to other cluster members. Normally (when no `outbound-ports` are configured), outbound connections to other cluster members use ephemeral ports allocated by the IP stack. Also, take into account that each member maintains a connection to every other member of the cluster, even those not listed in the tcp/ip members list.

This configuration means that you allow a hazelcast member to bind its server socket in 3331-3431 and also use ports in range 3330-3430 for the client-side port of its connections to other cluster members. This is a total of 102 ports to accommodate:
* N server socket ports, where N is the number of Hazelcast instances you start on a single physical box
* N*(M-1) client socket ports, where M is your cluster size

When you start 3 instances on each of your 9 boxes, you already use 3 + 3*(27-1)=81 ports. In order to accommodate a larger cluster, you need to widen your port range. Do you really want to restrict the outbound port range? If yes, I would make a cleaner separation between server and client socket port range eg:
- limit the amount of port increments to the actual number of instances I want to run on a single machine (add `port-count` to `hz:network` element)
- use a separate outbound port range for client-side socket ports

comment:
> @cestella: No, both the REPL and enrichments use the same method of assignment, the StellarAssignment class. It's just that assignment in stellar is available in multiple places.

Ah, yes, I am familiar with `StellarAssignment`.  Ok, but `StellarAssignment` just takes an expression as input and returns the variable and expression.  It gets us to the red zone, but not the end zone.

To really perform assignment, you still need to (1) execute the expression and (2) add the variable to a `VariableResolver`.  Those extra steps are performed currently in `AssignmentCommand` for the REPL and they must also be performed elsewhere for Enrichment, etc.

I was thinking that we would have all of those steps performed in the same place.

comment:
Hi,
will share few useful information on [lambda expression in java](http://beyondcorner.com/java-8-lambda-expression-features-tutorial-examples/)
use cases of java 8 on iterators
1. Java 8 lambda expression are mainly used to execute a block of code later, once or multiple times.

2. In Boolean expressions we can use lambda expression.

Example: (List list) -> list.isEmpty()

3. Using lambda expression we can Create a new objects.

Example: () -> new pet(“dog”, 13)

4. we can also used as consuming from an object.

Example: (Pet p) -> { System.out.println(p.getAgeMonths()); }

5. A lambda expression used to Select or extract from an object.

Example: (String s) -> s.length()

6. It produce a single value by performing computation on two values.

Example: (int a, int b) -> a * b

7. we can Compare two objects using lambda expression.

Example: (Pet  p1, Pet p2) -> p1.getAgeMonths().compareTo(p2.getAgeMonths())

comment:
**Comment by @noaaroland on 28 Sep 2006 15:39 UTC**
Repairs in svn revision: 432

Turns out that text constraints got (=,!=,<,<=,>, >=) from the UI and variable constraints got (eq, ne, lt, le, gt, ge) from the UI.  I changed the code to translate and transmit these as the two-letter value (eq, ne, lt, le, gt, ge).  They get translated back to the SQL style strings (=,!=,<,<=,>, >=) for the database backend are left as two-letter text (eq, ne, lt, le, gt, ge) for the Ferret backend.

The constraint type is now in the Ferret symbols.

comment:
> (Strange that .toString() returned [] but .isEmpty() returned false)

This is very weird because the object in question is a simple `Set<Long>`. Also we remove the contextId from the set in `sendFreeContext()` which is called (not directly) from the `run()` method of the search phase in the test. This is also where we count down the latch so it should no be possible for the test to get past the `latch.await()` with a search phase (and context) still in flight.

The only idea I have to progress this is to add a check before we countdown the latch to make sure its not already 0 (i.e. we are running something twice) and unmute the test to catch this again.

Would welcome any ideas others have on this too

comment:
So the solution is:


### 1. add register method into static block

For any library that needs to register into OSGL Tool, add a static block in the relevant class, say `org.osgl.csv.CsvParser`, something like:

```java
    static {
        IO.registerInputStreamHandler(MimeType.Trait.csv, new CsvInputStreamHandler());
    }
```

### 2. Add the full class name into a file named `osgl.ext.list` inside `src/main/resources` dir:

```
org.osgl.csv.CsvParser
```

### 3. The OSGL `Lang` class will trigger a logic that loads all resources named `osgl.ext.list`, for each line in the file, it will call `Class.forName` to load the class, which in turn will call the static block and hook that extension on.

Thanks @idelgado to jump in!
Can you confirm that my understanding of your explanation is correct:

Considering the following SDK method call:

```java
Voice.call(getReactApplicationContext(), accessToken, twiMLParams, callListener);
```

Could `twiMLParams` be a `Map` containing any arbitrary number of strings?
If so we could iterate over the Javascript object passed and convert it into a Java Map - which is strongly typed - omitting any key containing non string values.

comment:
> The "Usage" part uses val pmmlBytes = ConverterUtil.toPMMLByteArray(df.schema, pipelineModel)

The `ConverterUtil#toPMMLByteArray(StructType, PipelineModel)` has been deprecated, and should not be used anymore:
http://openscoring.io/blog/2018/07/09/converting_sparkml_pipeline_pmml/

> Is there a way to pass the missing value to this method?

You could iterate over `DataDictionary/DataField` elements, and manually add `<Value value="0" property="missing"/>` child elements to each of them.

Otherwise, looks like this functionality should be implemented as JPMML-XGBoost conversion option, so that it could be handled uniformly across ML frameworks.

comment:
The `static` block in A.class attempts to call `getClass()` on `null`.  This will always throw an NPE and should prevent A from being successfully initialized.

Since A wasn't successfully initialized, the `B.class.newInstance();` call should fail with an exception (that's why the rest of the code is in the finally block, right?)

I need to check the code but I believe `getDeclaredFields` forces class initialization before it attempts to find the fields.  Time to check the spec to see what is required when initialization fails.

comment:
>  Not supported for parameter

This exception means your factory doesn't override the createForParameter
method of SqlStatementCustomizerFactory.

The type that must be public is BindEventFactory and its default
constructor. Jdbi needs to be able to create an instance of the class you
link to in your annotation to be able to call its methods. For good
measure, try making the annotation public too and see.

Yes, putting a full code sample up here would be helpful.
--
Marnick "with ck, 3 capitals, and an apostrophe" L'Eau

comment:
So, folks, this issue seems to have come back to life, so let me clear up why it was something I never ended up implementing back in 2016. Basically, 

1. We wound up with enough question about the scope and semantics of this that I didn't think it felt sufficient "ripe":
    - were we aiming to include `?|>`, `*|>`?
    - was function composition going to be pulled into it? 
    - is partial application part of it?
2. @FroMage just wasn't very enthusiastic about the whole thing.

Now, it seems to me that this is a feature that's increasingly popular in other languages (apart from being something I've always liked) and it even looks like it's going to be part of JavaScript. So I think it's something we could safely move forward with. And I think we should stick with the "consensus" syntax of the other languages we've seen, i.e. `|>`.

Looking over what's being defined for JavaScript, I would say that a first cut of this could have a very similar scope, that is:

- the basic pipe operator `|>`, and
- partial application,

excluding function composition and the ascii-arty `?|>`, `*|>` for now.

Now, what's interesting about the above to included features is that, if I'm not mistaken, they can be defined as completely orthogonal features. We would introduce a syntax for partial application, something like this:

    Integer.format(?,16)

which would desugar to:

    (_) => Integer.format(_,16)

These partially applied functions would be usable anywhere, not only in "pipelines".

Similarly, the pipeline operator would be defined as above, namely:

    byte |> Integer.format(?,16) |> print

means:

    let (_1 = let (_2 = byte) Integer.format(?,16)(_2)) print(_1)

All this should be easy enough to implement via desugaring within the typechecker.

BIG QUESTION: I'm not very happy with `?` as the "wildcard character" for partial application, since in Ceylon, `?` always has something to do with optional types. Nor do I like `*`, since that always has something to do with multiplicity. So what alternatives do we have?

- `byte |> Integer.format(~,16) |> print`
- `byte |> Integer.format(#,16) |> print`
- `byte |> Integer.format(.,16) |> print`
- `byte |> Integer.format($,16) |> print`
- `byte |> Integer.format(&,16) |> print`
- `byte |> Integer.format(@,16) |> print`
- `byte |> Integer.format(%,16) |> print`
- `byte |> Integer.format(^,16) |> print`
- `byte |> Integer.format((),16) |> print`
- `byte |> Integer.format(!,16) |> print`
- `byte |> Integer.format(:,16) |> print`
- `byte |> Integer.format(...,16) |> print`

Anything else?

comment:
> In Kafka indexing service, the overlord does a sanity check that the start offsets of partitions of current publishing segments are same with the ones stored in metastore, so that it guarantees that all segments are published in order. Because of this check, some tasks might fail in this scenario.
> 
> 1. The supervisor created a task (`T1`) with a start offset `O1`.
> 2. Somehow, the supervisor couldn't send an endOffset `O2` to `T1` in `taskDuration`. Instead, it sent an endOffset `O3` to `T1` after `taskDuration * 10`. (In our case, supervisor couldn't send because of too frequent HTTP connection refused errors.)
> 3. `T1` started to merge, push, and publish segments.
> 4. The supervisor created a new task, `T2`, with a start offset `O3`.
> 5. After `taskDuration`, it sent an endOffset `O4` to `T2`.
> 6. `T2` started to merge, push, and publish segments.
> 7. Since `T1` had run for a much longer time, it had much more segments to publish than `T2`. As a result, `T2` tried to publish before `T1` complete publishing.
> 8. `T2` failed to publish because of the sanity check when updating metastore.
> 
> So, I think the supervisor should be able to guarantee segment publishing order across all running tasks like below.
> 
> ```
> T1: indexing ===> pushing ===> publishing ===> handoff
>               T2: indexing ===> pushing ===> publishing ===> handoff
>                             T3: indexing ===> pushing ===> publishing ===> handoff
>                                           ...
> ```
> To do so, I suppose the supervisor should be able to send pushing signals to kafka tasks as well as publishing signals.

good idea!

comment:
> I think the test you created is incorrect because the check has endpoint set to false in

Do you mean *endpoint* is `null` or *endpoint.isConnected()* returns `false`? The latter is actually what the test case is trying to illustrate, i.e. that the value of the *connected* field which has been updated in the thread that sent the CONNACK, is not (yet) visible in the thread that is handling the PUBLISH.

I agree that synchronizing access to the *connected* field should solve this problem. Have you checked, if the test case then succeeds?

comment:
> Call to 'Collection.toArray()' with zero-length array argument

I do not remember this particular case, all code is about 8 years old or even more.

from inspection description: 
>There are two styles to convert a collection to an array: either using a pre-sized array (like c.toArray(new String[c.size()])) or using an empty array (like c.toArray(new String[0]).
In older Java versions using pre-sized array was recommended, as the reflection call which is necessary to create an array of proper size was quite slow. However since late updates of OpenJDK 6 this call was intrinsified, making the performance of the empty array version the same and sometimes even better, compared to the pre-sized version. Also passing pre-sized array is dangerous for a concurrent or synchronized collection as a data race is possible between the size and toArray call which may result in extra nulls at the end of the array, if the collection was concurrently shrunk during the operation.
This inspection allows to follow the uniform style: either using an empty array (which is recommended in modern Java) or using a pre-sized array (which might be faster in older Java versions or non-HotSpot based JVMs).

comment:
The problem seems to be that the symbol solver cannot resolve the type of the expression used as a method argument, namely, `supportedProtocols.toArray(new String[supportedProtocols.size()])`. Therefore, it cannot resolve the method call expression where this argument is used in.

Now why the symbol solver isn't able to resolve the type of that expression, I can't tell. In order to resolve the type of this expression, it has to do a number of steps (e.g., resolve the type of the variable `supportedProtocols`, resolve the method declaration that corresponds to the call expression `supportedProtocols.toArray(...)`, for which the type of the argument to that method call has to be determined, etc.). Somewhere, this fails. It could be a configuration problem, i.e., maybe the symbol solver doesn't have all the necessary information (e.g., the type of `supportedProtocols` is a class that's defined in a piece of code that was not passed to the symbol solver); it could also be a bug in the symbol solver.

To narrow down the problem: What happens if you try to resolve the (simplified) expression `vSocket.setEnabledProtocols(new String[0])` ?

Will check 

> Am 01.02.2018 um 07:42 schrieb Rikki Gibson <notifications@github.com>:
> 
> Expected behavior
> 
> I can take a direct ByteBuffer where isReadOnly() is true, such as the return value of asReadOnlyBuffer() or a MappedBuffer with MapMode.READ_ONLY, pass it to Unpooled.wrappedBuffer(ByteBuffer), and write it to the channel.
> 
> Actual behavior
> 
> Works with NIO transport. When using kqueue or epoll native transport, writing to the channel fails due to UnsupportedOperationException produced by ReadOnlyByteBufferBuf.memoryAddress().
> 
> Minimal yet complete reproducer code
> 
> Bootstrap bootstrap = new Bootstrap();
> bootstrap.group(new KQueueEventLoopGroup());
> bootstrap.channel(KQueueSocketChannel.class);
> bootstrap.handler(new ChannelInitializer<SocketChannel>() {
>     @Override
>     protected void initChannel(SocketChannel ch) throws Exception {
>         ch.pipeline().addLast("HttpResponseDecoder", new HttpResponseDecoder());
>         ch.pipeline().addLast("HttpRequestEncoder", new HttpRequestEncoder());
>     }
> });
> 
> final Path path = Paths.get("src/test/resources/upload.txt");
> final FileChannel fileChannel = FileChannel.open(path, StandardOpenOption.READ);
> 
> final ByteBuffer dst = ByteBuffer.allocateDirect((int) fileChannel.size());
> fileChannel.read(dst, 0);
> dst.flip();
> 
> bootstrap.connect("httpbin.org", 80).addListener(new ChannelFutureListener() {
>     @Override
>     public void operationComplete(ChannelFuture future) throws Exception {
>         final Channel channel = future.channel();
>         DefaultHttpHeaders headers = new DefaultHttpHeaders();
>         headers.add("Content-Length", fileChannel.size());
>         DefaultHttpRequest req = new DefaultHttpRequest(HttpVersion.HTTP_1_1, HttpMethod.POST, "/post", headers);
>         channel.write(req);
>         channel.write(Unpooled.wrappedBuffer(dst.asReadOnlyBuffer()));
>         channel.writeAndFlush(DefaultLastHttpContent.EMPTY_LAST_CONTENT).addListener(new GenericFutureListener<Future<? super Void>>() {
>             @Override
>             public void operationComplete(Future<? super Void> future) throws Exception {
>                 if (!future.isSuccess()) {
>                     future.cause().printStackTrace();
>                 }
>             }
>         });
>     }
> });

label: non-relevant

comment:
The responsibility of the deserializer is to treat incoming strings as ISO currency codes and deserialize them as `CurrencyUnit`. The only special handling that I'd accept is `null` (in JSON) should become `null` (in Java). Empty strings are not `null` and they shouldn't be treated as equals.

Are you in control of the client that issues the request? Why can't you modify it to send the correct value?
caveat: Two MBeanInfo objects are equal if and only if they return equal values for getClassName(), for getDescription(), and for getDescriptor(), and the arrays returned by the two objects for getAttributes(), getOperations(), getConstructors(), and getNotifications() are pairwise equal.
label: non-relevant

找到问题了。我犯了一下两点错误：1.ASE128的情况下，password必须用16位的字符串才可以；2.如果想跟其他地方的项目的加密对应的话，SecretKey对象使用自己的key创造的对象，如 **SecretKeySpec key = new SecretKeySpec(“你自己的key”.getBytes(), "AES");**，而不是由** KeyGenerator**生成的。

希望对大家有帮助。

十分感谢作者提供的项目。

comment:
Some more investigations showed that at the time when the Headers are parse the input for parsing seems to be invalid. In Glassfish 4.1.2.2 you can see the correct header but in Glassfish 5.0 it seems to be the response already.

Relevant code location: `org.glassfish.grizzly.http.HttpCodecFilter#decodeHttpPacketFromBytes` (line 237 Glassfish 50). 

However I think that this is not the root cause. I think the issue is that provided input buffer contains the wrong content. And this again is retrieved from `org.glassfish.grizzly.filterchain.FilterChainContext#getMessage`.
caveat: Report the message associated with this error
label: non-relevant

comment:
It looks like you have a few problems if this is all of the code you have written so far

- the `for` loop in `getMessage()` uses the same instance (`amessage`) of `Message` for every object you are iterating through without changing it any, this might be why you are seeing the same message repeated
- it looks like both the `Author` and `Message` classes are designed to pull from the `messData` object each time they need to get data, these classes could hold that data though instead of looking it up each time they need to get it

Hopefully if you look at those items it will lead you in the right direction.
caveat: Report the message associated with this error
label: non-relevant

comment: @Jetlagh Is `comboBox.setValue(event.getObject());` basically the same as `comboBox.getSelectionModel().select(event.getObject());` in your example? If yes, is this generally valid or does it apply only to this example? What does the following extract from the JavaDoc of ComboBox mean exactly? "The value property is not constrained to items contained within the items list - it can be anything as long as it is a valid value of type T."
caveat: ClassNotLoadedException if the field type has not yet been loaded through the appropriate class loader.
label: non-relevant

comment: The problem here is that there is no generic way of testing whether the object passed to `setValue` is actually present. It would be doable by iterating through all items when `setItems` is used, but we wouldn't want to iterate through the entire database if a lazy-loading `DataProvider` is used to find items.

comment:
This can be caused by various things:
* Connection to Redis is disconnected (`connection.isOpen()` returns `false`)
* The connection is blocked by a previous command
* The connection is in a transactional state (`connection.isMulti()` returns `true`)

comment:
> If I'm not mistaken, AbstractData#getValue always returns a Value wrapped in Optional, and AbstractImmutableData#getValue always returns an ImmutableValue wrapped in Optional(I recognize that ensuring E is upto the plugin developer).


You're confusing the *declared type* versus the *instance type*. Yes the internal `Map` declares the entries as `Supplier<Optional<Value<?>>` etc. but the actual return type has the contract of *at least returning the type `Value`* whereas the actual implementation of many [differs based on the `Key` used as demonstrated in some implementations](https://github.com/SpongePowered/SpongeCommon/blob/bleeding/src/main/java/org/spongepowered/common/data/manipulator/mutable/SpongeFireworkRocketData.java#L51) which end up being type checked based on the contracted methods.




> Does this imply that, for example, given a key that expects a Value<Int> from one manipulator, manipulator.asImmutable().getValue(key) should equal Optional.empty() because the immutable version does not have the corresponding mutable Value?

Remember that the Values and Manipulators are contracted to have guaranteed equivalency when transferring from mutable -> immutable -> mutable such that the values are the same, and if the value is a bounded value, the bounds would likewise be the same. The one aspect of differences is that we're always passing the underlying raw value (whether it's an `int`, `boolean`, `String`, `List<PotionEffect>` etc.) to create either a new `Value`/`ImmutableValue` or [if it's possible to retrieve a cached `ImmutableValue`](https://github.com/SpongePowered/SpongeCommon/blob/bleeding/src/main/java/org/spongepowered/common/data/ImmutableDataCachingUtil.java#L98).

comment:
### Variables(serializable)

In engine layer, we can handle variables by using Java APIs like RuntimeService.setVariable/getVariable.If the parameter value over the argument of RuntimeService.setVariable matches the following conditions, the variable is stored in the database as binary(Table ACT_GE_BYTEARRAY Column BYTES_).

* Condition
  * byte[]
    * https://github.com/Activiti/Activiti/blob/develop/activiti-engine/src/main/java/org/activiti/engine/impl/variable/ByteArrayType.java
  * A character string of 4000 or more characters
    * https://github.com/Activiti/Activiti/blob/develop/activiti-engine/src/main/java/org/activiti/engine/impl/variable/LongStringType.java
  * com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.JsonNode
    * https://github.com/Activiti/Activiti/blob/develop/activiti-engine/src/main/java/org/activiti/engine/impl/variable/LongJsonType.java
  * java.io.Serializable
    * https://github.com/Activiti/Activiti/blob/develop/activiti-engine/src/main/java/org/activiti/engine/impl/variable/SerializableType.java

### Cause of this issue

* When the API that acquires the variable is called, the following processing is performed in the internal processing of the Engine, and then the variable is returned to the caller.
  * If variable's type is serializable, engine get value by fetching Table ACT_GE_BYTEARRAY.
  * Engine deserialize value to each data type(byte[], String, JsonNode, Serializable).

* In the APIs(RuntimeService.getVariableInstances/getVariableInstancesLocal) of this issue , the above processing is not executed inside the Engine. So, when the caller access value, the caller try to fetch binary value from ACT_GE_BYTEARRAY. But, since outside of Engine, NullPointerException occurs.
caveat: In addition, this object's minimum buffer size must be at least as large as that of the object specified, its maximum buffer size must be at most as large as that of the object specified, and all of its formats must match formats supported by the object specified.
label: non-relevant

> Given these challenges, the proposal is to introduce JoinNode#matchMax property that says "Each probe row must produce no more then specified number of matches". Doing so would allow to eliminate the extra AssignUniqueId, MarkDistinct and Filter nodes as well as remote and local exchanges between MarkDistinct and JoinNode and corresponding hash generations.

Alternatively we could create plan with `MarkDistinct[all_probe_rows]` and then capture plan pattern of:
```
- MarkDistinct[all_probe_rows]
  - LeftJoin[...]
    - AssignUniqueId[unique] 
```
and rewrite it to:
```
- MarkDistinct[unique]
  - LeftJoin[...]
    - AssignUniqueId[unique] 
```
Basically we could have a `MarkDistinct` simplification rule that removes symbols of stream local properties are:
```
Grouped[unique], Constant[rest_probe_rows]
``` 
which is I believe what you did

comment:
In case any future readers are trying to write code to parse XML with this problem:

The `��` are malformed XML entities. They are two unsigned shorts forming a single UTF-16 emoji character. This is not proper XML, but it can be fixed without too much hassle. [Here's a gist](https://gist.github.com/Calvin-L/5232f876b8acf48a216941b8904632bb) I wrote that has a `fix_codepoints` function to fix such malformed inputs:

```
$ python3
>>> from entityfixer import fix_codepoints
>>> fix_codepoints("��")
'😆'
>>> fix_codepoints("��", raw=False)
'😆'
>>> fix_codepoints("��", raw=True)
'😆'
```

Someone else might find it useful.

comment:
@KES777  the issue is that DBeaver is formatting the time to your user timezone and then *HORRIBLY* not including the offset or timezone abbreviation in the output. You should see a timezone abbreviation in the bottom of your status bar that indicates this. This results in *very* confusion output from UTC datetimes from PostgreSQL as you're running in to.

I've not been able to affect the `user.timezone` system property with DBeaver command line arguments in Linux.   


```
export JAVA_OPTS="-Duser.timezone=UTC"
export _JAVA_OPTS="-Duser.timezone=UTC"
dbeaver -vmwargs -Duser.timezone=UTC
dbeaver -vmwargs=-Duser.timezone=UTC
dbeaver -vmwargs="-Duser.timezone=UTC"
```

will all result in DBeaver still reporting the timezone as "EST" upon startup and formatting `Timestamps` accordingly.

The only way I've found that can actually change DBeaver's timezone is by editing the *system* dbeaver.ini file to add `-Duser.timezone=UTC`

It would be a much less confusing default if DBeaver would at least put the timezone name or offset that it is applying to datetime/timestamp values when formatting them.

comment:
Step 3 cannot be part of the current generic `expand` method exactly for the reason that it should only apply the full size in one of the directions, while not touching the other direction. For this reason, FW8 has technically unrelated implementations of `addComponentsAndExpand` in `VerticalLayout` and in `HorizontalLayout`.

The only design discussion I remember from FW8 was the exact naming of the method. Only `expand` was vague and bad for discoverability compared to other `addComponent` methods. `addAndExpand` would have been better, but still not clear what was added in the context of FW8 where all other methods that added children also included `Component` in the name.

For Flow, I think `addAndExpand` would be better since it's in line with only using `add` for adding children.

comment:
```
java.lang.IllegalStateException: STREAM
	at org.eclipse.jetty.server.Response.getWriter(Response.java:931)
	at javax.servlet.ServletResponseWrapper.getWriter(ServletResponseWrapper.java:109)
	at org.eclipse.jgit.lfs.server.fs.FileLfsServlet.sendError(FileLfsServlet.java:181)
	at org.eclipse.jgit.lfs.server.fs.ObjectDownloadListener.onError(ObjectDownloadListener.java:152)
```

That says your `HttpServletResponse` output mode is currently STREAM (something has used `HttpServletResponse.getOutputStream()`), but your `sendError()` attempted to use `HttpServletResponse.getWriter()` which is a violation of the Servlet contract, you can be either STREAM or WRITE but not swap between them.  You can can use `HttpServletResponse.reset()` to reset the STREAM vs WRITER mode if you want (but be sure you understand all of the implications of `reset()` see javadoc)

Your `FileLfsServlet.sendError()` should also check for `HttpServletResponse.isCommitted()` before attempting to send an error (you can't do anything useful if the response is committed)

comment:
The problem is that when `SecureDfuImpl.sendFirmware(BluetoothGatt)` tries to resume it tries to read all the executed bytes (L495) from the stream but since the stream is reused (and not reset to the beginning of the file) it instead reads the rest of the file (and thus setting `currentSource` to `null`). On the next read (L499) the NPE occurs.

I'm not sure there is a simple solution to this.

There also seem to be some confusion/mismatch in how the `mark`/`reset` methods are used in the code. In some places it seems like it is assumed that `reset` resets the stream to the beginning.

comment:
They modify the hitbox every tick:
https://github.com/Tropicraft/Tropicraft/blob/1.12.2/src/main/java/net/tropicraft/core/common/event/ScubaHandlerCommon.java

So my hypothesis stands, it's a hitbox issue. When the hitbox is changed to something else, it can cause the player to move to compensate for collisions. This is fine if it momentarily changes when morphing to something else, as is the case with only Metamorph installed. However, in this case, Metamorph and Tropicraft are both fighting to change the hitbox. Metamorph has to change the hitbox when the player is in a morph, because vanilla code changes the hitbox back every tick. So, assuming this is a hitbox issue, Tropicraft should not update the player hitbox while the player is morphed.

comment:
I closed the PR now and created a new one with the most trivial fix one could think of:

From the callstack we can see that the exception is thrown in the Method JobProxy.cleanUpOrphanedJob when if calls jobApi.isSupported(context).

The call to isSupported was not inside a try block, and that's why the whole thing ended up in an "unhandled" Exception (=Crash).

With the latest PR I have simply moved the call to isSupported() to the inside of the try block.
That should definetely fix the situation and doesn't impose any significant risk for regressions.

I hope you'll find this change acceptable, so that we can finally settle this issue... :-)

Thanks a lot for your patience :-)

Hi @dekobon,

This exception just says that besides defining a type, you need to define standard operations on the type (NOT_EQUAL, EQUAL, GREATER_THAN_OR_EQUAL, HASH_CODE, LESS_THAN, BETWEEN, LESS_THAN_OR_EQUAL, GREATER_THAN).

comment:
We noticed that using `java.lang.HashMap` instead of `ValueHashMap` improves the performance in this case by the factor of 3.  Hash values for ValueDouble end mostly on '000001', resulting in multiple hash collisions. Java HashMap still works reasonable fast in this case, but ValueHashMap does not.

It looks like ValueHashMap is using open addressing hashing with linear probing and the later is really bad when you have a lot of collisions.

I tried to redo `ValueHashMap` as just an extension of `java.lang.HashMap`. All regression tests passed and as I mentioned before the speed seems to be better. What are the advantages of using `ValueHashMap` instead of `java.lang.HashMap`?

Additional note:
The method `hashCode`  for `ValueDouble` is slightly different from the method `hashCode`  for `java.lang.Double` ( >> vs >>>). The difference has no effect in this case, just something I noticed. 

Additional note:
For String values using `java.lang.HashMap` is also faster then `ValueHashMap`.
caveat: Note that two BigDecimal objects that are numerically equal but differ in scale (like 2.0 and 2.00) will generally not have the same hash code.
label: non-relevant

comment: Strings are ubiquitous and are reasonably fast to compare if their hashCode()'s do not collide nor happens to be zero. So, I propose that we should use four groups: primitives first, wrappers second, strings third and everything else last.

Hi @dpreussler,

We do indeed need to ensure that the returned object is of the correct type; otherwise, method invocations will fail against an incompatible target object.

Comparing the names would not suffice, since a factory could return a proxy for the test class type.

With regard to using a different `ClassLoader` to instantiate the test class, that is a topic that has been discussed in #201 but never finalized.

Perhaps we should extract the `TestInstanceClassLoaderProvider` proposal from #201 (or simply a `ClassLoaderProvider` or `ClassLoaderFactory`) and push that out with 5.3.

That would of course delay the 5.3 release, but it may be a good idea to publish that now alongside `TestInstanceFactory` and the parallel test execution support coming in 5.3.

@junit-team/junit-lambda, thoughts?

comment:
There is an allocation happening in the above code: The `nvgFontFace(NVG_ID, font.getName());` call must serialize the font name string and LWJGL currently allocates a `ByteBuffer` via the `MemoryStack` internally. Assuming nothing else allocates, this would account for ~400k instances at 20k fps.

But, this would only happen when running inside a profiler which, ironically, screws up with escape analysis and you end up with useless measurements. Running `nvgFontFace` in a tight loop produces zero garbage normally, EA eliminates the `ByteBuffer` allocation.

So, two questions:

- Is it really a memory leak? Does memory usage continuously increase and never goes down after a GC?
caveat: The default value is null, indicating that normal resolution of a Font from attributes should be performed.

comment:
When you register a recipe, the output multiplier specified in the recipe gets used. It happens to default to 2, but other values are possible.

The effective formula is: Recipe Output Multiplier * Axe Level Multiplier * Fortune
If that number is not a whole integer, the remainder is used to decide if it rounds up or down. So: 1.2 would be 1 item + 20% chance of an extra.

comment:
An object used as key needs to be immutable and needs to produce identical hash codes. The rules for key objects are identical to those of the Map interface. Other caches will have trouble with your key as well.

When removing an entry, cache2k checks whether the key is still producing the same hash code. This is a counter measure to detect keys that are mutated. In your case it detects not a key mutation, but that the actual key content is gone.

The `HttpServletRequest` is not ideal for a cache key. It is heavy weight and has a life time bound to the request. The `HttpServletRequest` might get wrapped also. A key should be as compact as possible and uniquely identify the cached resource and immutable. 

Solutions:

For logging purposes we generate a unique request ID per request and hold that as request attribute and as thread local variable. That is a string identifying the request, which would be perfect for a cache key.

The other question is why you need a cache at all, and don't store your context object in the request attribute directly (`HttpServletRequest.setAttribute` / `getAttribute`)

Hope that helps. Happy to discuss this more.
caveat: In this implementation, the operation descriptor must be specified correctly and assigned to the modelMBeanInfo so that the 'setMethod' works correctly.
label: non-relevant

comment:
This change assumed that attribute values are immutable, which is not necessary the case.

For example, what if the value is a StringBuffer. A controller does getAttribute to get the StringBuffer object, calls .append on it, then calls setAttribute to persist it. Currently, this would behave as expected. With this proposed changed, the appended data would be lost, as the object reference has not changed (and the same object reference .equals itself).
caveat: In this implementation, the operation descriptor must be specified correctly and assigned to the modelMBeanInfo so that the 'setMethod' works correctly.

comment:
So here's generally what happens with the queue daos
- Messages get put on the queue with an ACK timeout value
- Messages get popped when workers poll for them, MySQL queue DAO sets `popped = 1` so we can un-pop them at a later time if need be
- Workers will ACK the tasks as they get them, which in the case of the MySQL queue DAO will delete the row
- If Workers do not ACK the task in a certain amount of time, the messages that were popped should re-appear in the queue, this simply sets `popped = 0` so it reappears the next time messages are peeked/popped
- `QueueDAO::processUnacks` is the method that will evaluate all popped messages for tasks that need to be un-popped, but this method does not get called regularly by any external sweeper code

Why does the Redis QueueDAO work correctly? It has internally configured a thread pool for calling its unack processing on a regular interval, check the `RedisDynoQueueDAO` constructor.

The fix for MySqlQueueDAO is pretty much the same as the implementation in RedisDynoQueueDAO and it should be posted in a bit.
caveat: timeout how long to wait before giving up, in units of unit
label: non-relevant

comment:
@iliassk One other thing to note is that exclusion of "default" values should allow this, as long as POJO implements `equals()` properly: if POJO was `NON_DEFAULT` class annotation, then POJO-valued properties are checked same as everything else: an instance is constructed using 0-argument constructor, and this instance is compared to (non-null) value, and value is excluded if they equal.

There is also the newish option of "custom" filter for `@JsonInclude`, see:

https://medium.com/@cowtowncoder/jackson-2-9-features-b2a19029e9ff

which does allow any kind of logic you want.

There are no current plans aside from these options however: amount of work involved in implementing various strategies is practically unlimited so I'd prefer to cap it by allowing extension by others at this point.
But I am always open to suggestions on possible techniques for new features.

comment:
An object used as key needs to be immutable and needs to produce identical hash codes. The rules for key objects are identical to those of the Map interface. Other caches will have trouble with your key as well.

When removing an entry, cache2k checks whether the key is still producing the same hash code. This is a counter measure to detect keys that are mutated. In your case it detects not a key mutation, but that the actual key content is gone.

The `HttpServletRequest` is not ideal for a cache key. It is heavy weight and has a life time bound to the request. The `HttpServletRequest` might get wrapped also. A key should be as compact as possible and uniquely identify the cached resource and immutable. 

Solutions:

For logging purposes we generate a unique request ID per request and hold that as request attribute and as thread local variable. That is a string identifying the request, which would be perfect for a cache key.

The other question is why you need a cache at all, and don't store your context object in the request attribute directly (`HttpServletRequest.setAttribute` / `getAttribute`)

Hope that helps. Happy to discuss this more.

comment:
> (Strange that .toString() returned [] but .isEmpty() returned false)

This is very weird because the object in question is a simple `Set<Long>`. Also we remove the contextId from the set in `sendFreeContext()` which is called (not directly) from the `run()` method of the search phase in the test. This is also where we count down the latch so it should no be possible for the test to get past the `latch.await()` with a search phase (and context) still in flight.

The only idea I have to progress this is to add a check before we countdown the latch to make sure its not already 0 (i.e. we are running something twice) and unmute the test to catch this again.

Would welcome any ideas others have on this too

comment:
@bbejeck I've made a pass over your replies (thanks!) and I think the only ones that I'm not fully understanding is due to the fact that I've not seen the full picture, but only the first PR yet, namely:

1. In some graph nodes we are passing processor node names, KTableSource objects, which to me are physical plan related classes and should not be included in the logical plans (e.g. I was thinking we should be only creating processor node names when we are actually generating the processor node).

2. We are keeping a parent name, plus parent node reference, which is a bit redundant to me.

3. ProcessorParameters is used to collapse multiple parameters, while in some places we still have `name` and `StateStoreSupplier` as two separate parameters, we could just reuse it (but again, I'm not fully understanding why we need to store the `name` if it is for the processor name).

More generally, today there are multiple categories of "names", i.e. `processor node name` for physical processor node, `streams graph node name` for logical graph node, `state store name`, `topic name`, we need to clearly distinguish them by the field names, otherwise it could be quite confusing. For example, in `RepartitionNode`, `sourceName` -> `sourceProcessorNodeName`, `sinkName` -> `sinkProcessorNodeName`, `processorName` -> `mapProcessorNodeName`: but I'm still not clear why the node names have to be determined beforehand..

Anyways, I can go ahead and merge the PR as is if you think these questions are better answerable in the follow-up PRs.

comment:
> Personally, I think that we should (a) document that we start at zero

Yeah, it's definitely worth marking current `ENUM` support as experimental, warning people that the implementation might change incompatibly. I've noticed a few interesting things, too

> disallow such operations until we have a convincing use-case

It depends. The expected behaviour of string concatenation is very obvious...

> But ordinal values of enumerators are still different. 'A' is 1 and 'B' is 2 in MySQL. H2 uses 0 and 1 for them.

In SQL, if in doubt, always start counting at 1. Of course, H2 has other places where this is "wrong", e.g. the following yields 2, not 1: `SELECT (1, 2)[1]`

> ENUM is not a standard thing. Only MySQL and its forks originally had such data type. H2 implementation looks like MySQL-compatible, but casts and arithmetic have off-by-one difference. I don't know if compatibility with them is desired or not.

Don't forget PostgreSQL's enum type, which is cleaner than MySQL's, IMO. I think that compatibility is very essential here, especially since MySQL's DDL syntax was mimicked already, it is not wrong to expect compatibility as a user.

> We cannot disallow casts because they are used internally for reading from storages. So disallowing of arithmetic operators also makes a very little sense.

I agree that casts must be allowed. In many cases, an `ENUM` is "just" a fancy check constraint (given that MySQL doesn't even support them) plus a storage optimisation. But when reading enums, they often act like `VARCHAR`, so it should be possible to treat them like varchar, at least when used explicitly.

      - "no_sslv3"

##    - "no_tlsv1_1"
##    - "cipher_server_preference"
##    - "no_compression"
   'DHFILE': "File path" # generated with: openssl dhparam -out dhparams.pem 2048

##
## listen: The ports ejabberd will listen on, which service each is handled
## by and what options to start it with.
##

listen:
  -
    port: 5222
    ip: "::"
    module: ejabberd_c2s
    ##
    ## If TLS is compiled in and you installed a SSL
    ## certificate, specify the full path to the
    ## file and uncomment these lines:
    ##
    starttls: true
    certfile: 'CERTFILE'
    protocol_options: 'TLSOPTS'
    dhfile: 'DHFILE'
    ciphers: 'CIPHERS'
    ##
    ## To enforce TLS encryption for client connections,
    ## use this instead of the "starttls" option:
    ##
    starttls_required: true
    ##
    ## Stream compression
    ##
    ## zlib: true
    ##
    max_stanza_size: 65536
    shaper: c2s_shaper
    access: c2s
 -
    port: 5269
    ip: "::"
    module: ejabberd_s2s_in
  -
    port: 5280
    ip: "::"
    module: ejabberd_http
    tls: true
    ## starttls: true
    certfile: 'CERTFILE'
    protocol_options: 'TLSOPTS'
    dhfile: 'DHFILE'
    ciphers: 'CIPHERS'
    http_bind: true
    request_handlers:
      "/ws": ejabberd_http_ws
      "/bosh": mod_bosh
      "/api": mod_http_api
    ##  "/pub/archive": mod_http_fileserver
    web_admin: true
    ## register: true
    captcha: true
###'  S2S GLOBAL OPTIONS

##
## s2s_use_starttls: Enable STARTTLS for S2S connections.
## Allowed values are: false, optional or required
## You must specify a certificate file.
##
s2s_use_starttls: required

##

## Custom OpenSSL options

comment:
This is because the Spark framework ([MesosCoarseGrainedScheduler](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/v2.3.0/resource-managers/mesos/src/test/scala/org/apache/spark/scheduler/cluster/mesos/MesosCoarseGrainedSchedulerBackendSuite.scala)) is thrown off by `${MESOS_DIRECTORY}` which is set to the host path which is bind mounted into the container as `${MESOS_SANDBOX}` (`/mnt/mesos/sandbox`).

If running in a container, `${MESOS_DIRECTORY}` must be [remapped ](https://github.com/vishnu2kmohan/beakerx-dcos-docker/blob/master/jupyter_notebook_config.py#L59) directly to `/mnt/mesos/sandbox` (or some other directly accessible and writeable location within the container - e.g., [`/tmp`](https://github.com/mesosphere/spark-build/blob/master/conf/spark-env.sh#L34-L36))

Note: If you're running the Jupyter Notebook as a container on Apache Mesos or Mesosphere DC/OS you must further [unset](https://github.com/vishnu2kmohan/beakerx-dcos-docker/blob/master/jupyter_notebook_config.py#L61-L66) some environment variables that will interfere with the Spark Driver:
```
MESOS_EXECUTOR_ID
MESOS_FRAMEWORK_ID
MESOS_SLAVE_ID
MESOS_SLAVE_PID
MESOS_TASK_ID
```

comment: Looking at the stack trace, I think the problem is in `getSource` in `SourceFactory.java`, specifically https://github.com/eXist-db/exist/blob/develop/src/org/exist/source/SourceFactory.java#L76-L139. Instead of getting to lines 123-134 (where "any other URL" should be handled), the code thinks the URL is an xmldb URI and so tries to handle the URI up above in lines 90-100. I think the change was introduced by @adamretter in https://github.com/eXist-db/exist/commit/f07db94aad4e1685f30ccd10532df3e1899199a4#diff-ef7f3227bbd557c4b7b9605cc4a74521. Seeing as that was an attempt to fix https://github.com/eXist-db/exist/issues/1927, it's clear that we introduced an unintentional assumption that module imports without `xmldb:exist:` actually should be handled as xmldb URIs.

comment:
You need to use ExecutionInput to specify it

```
        HashMap<String,Object> variablesMap = new HashMap<>();
        variablesMap.put("var1","value1");
        
        ExecutionInput executionInput = ExecutionInput.newExecutionInput()
                .query('{ yourquery { name } }')
                .variables(variablesMap)
                .context(new SomeContextObject())
                .root(new SomeRootThing())
                .build();
```

The roor is fixed for the life of the query.  It also is the seed for the `environment.getSource()`

Each object returned then becomes the new `environment.getSource()` as you descend the query.

The context is also an object of your choosing.  Its a helper for you in every data fetcher for "context"

comment:
One of the previous version of JoinNode has a check like this
`checkArgument(inputSymbols.containsAll(outputSymbols), "Left and right join inputs do not contain all output symbols")` 
which increased the planning time but replacing with 

`checkArgument(new HashSet<>(inputSymbols).containsAll(outputSymbols), "Left and right join inputs do not contain all output symbols")`
doesn't show much of a performance difference.

Moreover removing the check for `TableScanNode` and for `JoinNode` didn't gave much of a difference. The main part of the validation code which takes more time for join is 

```          
List<Integer> rightSymbolIndexes = node.getRight().getOutputSymbols().stream()
    .filter(symbol -> node.getOutputSymbols().contains(symbol))
    .map(symbol -> node.getOutputSymbols().indexOf(symbol))
    .collect(toImmutableList());

boolean allLeftBeforeRight = node.getLeft().getOutputSymbols().stream()
    .filter(symbol -> node.getOutputSymbols().contains(symbol))
    .map(symbol -> node.getOutputSymbols().indexOf(symbol))
    .allMatch(leftIndex -> rightSymbolIndexes.stream()
        .allMatch(rightIndex -> rightIndex > leftIndex));
```

If we could just check the index of the first symbol from the right relation and the last symbol from the left relation and make sure that all left symbols are before right.

comment:
There's a side effect in your `isVisible` method: the marker can be outside of the bounding box but visible on the screen. For instance if it's just outside in the corner but with a centered 21x21 bitmap, we should see something like a 10x10 part of the bitmap.

> so that seem to include tiles which are not on the screen

Correct: not only the displayed tiles are impacted by the refresh, because for instance of the pre-cache, or of the rotation mode. Basically, we're talking about tiles that are related to the current displayed tiles. Or do you see totally unrelated tiles in the logs? That would definitely be a bug.

comment:
Re: isVisible - what is implemented in osmdroid is "before you draw a marker, check first if it is visible" (in `Marker.drawAt`). That way we may skip the draw part, which makes things a bit faster. But that's part of the whole `invalidate` process.

Re: unrelated tiles - if you really want to check if irrelevant tiles are being processed, you need perhaps to add debug logs in `TilesOverlay.OverlayTileLooper.handleTile`. But I don't think you'll find anything.

I would say that you already have your answers for this issue: it's normal to have the whole display refreshed when you add a `Marker`, and that shouldn't be a performance issue anyway.

comment:
> Yes, here the minimum coordinate are used , 0:0 , you use the maximum for Y, but if You use values between, for complexer situations, it works as it should, not with you'r modification.

Things are **not** as complicated as you describe them. I try to explain why. 

There are two coordinate systems.

1. The first coordinate system is the G Code controller's machine coordinate system. Due to imperfections in the simple mechanics and tools we mostly use (not to mention varying skills), this machine coordinate may be physically non-square. There could be many imperfections like bent rails, but the only one OpenPNP can compensate for, is where the angle between the X and Y axes is not perfectly 90° (typically by far the largest imperfection in a maker built machine, I guess). 
2. The second coordinate system is the internal OpenPNP coordinate system that must be square, because we want to blindly populate the PCB which is professionally manufactured and therefore pretty square. 

Whenever a square coordinate from OpenPNP is sent to the machine, the non-squareness factor is [applied in GcodeDriver.java:513](https://github.com/openpnp/openpnp/blob/998241d4942309d664721bf5497bdd77f7f7a0f4/src/main/java/org/openpnp/machine/reference/driver/GcodeDriver.java#L513)
```
command = substituteVariable(command, "X", x + nonSquarenessFactor * y);
command = substituteVariable(command, "BacklashOffsetX", x + backlashOffsetX + nonSquarenessFactor * y); // Backlash Compensation
```

As you see, this is very simple: `x + nonSquarenessFactor * y`. There is no `if`, no `abs()` handling signs, just a linear expression. This means that this transformation works seamlessly from the negative to zero and into the positive for all numbers x, y and nonSquarenessFactor. Mathematically it is absolutely irrelevant whether your homing location, fiducial or your origin is at the maximum, the minimum, in the middle or even beyond endstops of any axis. 

On moves, the internal coordinate is transformed into the machine coordinate. The information flows from OpenPNP to the machine. There is one tiny moment, when this goes the other way around. Just after electromechanical and/or visual homing, you pin down the machine coordinates with G92. There you have to realize that the information flows the other way. The information **is the current machine position** and it flows back **into** the current internal position of OpenPNP. Therefore we have to take the coordinate from the machine coordinate system and transform it into the internal OpenPNP coordinate system. If Y home is zero, this can be ignored, because with `x + nonSquarenessFactor * y` there is no difference (multiplication by zero). But if Y is non-zero, we must compensate for that. Because the information is flowing the other way, we must inverse the non-squareness transformation. This is easy: we just flip the sign from plus to minus: `x - nonSquarenessFactor * y`.  It is easy to see, that the inverse of adding something is subtracting that same something, right? 

Again this is very simple.  Again no `if`, no `abs()` handling signs just a linear expression. Again this means that this transformation works seamlessly from the negative to zero and into the positive. Again there can be no difference whether your homing location, fiducial or your origin is at the maximum, the minimum, in the middle or even beyond endstops of any axis. 

Lets play this through: Say we home to X0 Y500 and we have a non-squareness factor of 0.001. So for the machine the home is at X0 Y500. In the current, faulty code, OpenPNP now **also** thinks it is at X0 Y500. But when OpenPNP wants to move to X0 Y500, it uses the non-squareness transformation `x + nonSquarenessFactor * y` and sends G0 X0.5 Y500 to the machine. If you homed using a fiducial you will now notice the offset/bug. 

Now with my bugfix OpenPNP will transform the machine homing location X0 X500 back using `x - nonSquarenessFactor * y` and correctly think it is at X-0.5 Y500 after homing. When it now wants to move back to the homing location at X-0.5 Y500 it uses the non-squareness transformation `x + nonSquarenessFactor * y` and sends G0 X0 Y500 to the machine. Perfect!

You can think this through with any signs and numbers. If you find a case where this does not work, please document! You'll probably get the Nobel price for revolutionizing Linear Algebra :)

comment:
I think the problem is that `SQLMetadataRuleManager.poll()` is scheduled to be called asynchronously in a dedicated executor in `SQLMetadataRuleManager.start()`. `poll()` makes an inner join of the rules table with itself, that appears to be enough to cause a deadlock when the drop of this table is called in parallel (it is called in `SQLMetadataRuleManagerTest.cleanup()`.

The problem was introduced in #5554, where the `SQLMetadataRuleManagerTest.testMultipleStopAndStart()` was added which calls `start()` and `stop()` repeatedly. Before, `SQLMetadataRuleManager.start()` was not ever called in the context of `SQLMetadataRuleManagerTest`.

Extra coincidental problem that leads to this condition is that `stop()` (that pairs `start()` calls in `testMultipleStopAndStart()` is not actually synchronous at the moment. By the time when `stop()` exists, some `poll()` may still be executed. To ensure this is not the case, `exec.awaitTermination()` should be called. But this is awkward, because we don't know what timeout we should use. Alternatively, `poll()` could be synchronized together with `start()` and `stop()` (the `started` flag should be checked under the lock in `poll()`).

Extra:
 - There is no point of `future` and `exec` being volatile.
 - `future.cancel` is redundant before `shutdownNow()`.
 - There is a race on `retryStartTime` updates in `poll()`.
 - It feels to me that `SQLMetadataRuleManager` mixes two separate abstractions - one of scheduled polling, and another of the access to the database itself (including the implementation of `poll()`). But I'm uncertain about this.
caveat: Note that calling this method from within the run method of a timer task that was invoked by this timer absolutely guarantees that the ongoing task execution is the last task execution that will ever be performed by this timer.

Hi Stefan,
In the Model coming out of the first RDBMS Reader is the Entity name 'kpis' and the attribute name 'id'?

In the second RDBMS Reader the reference to the Input Model must match the entity.attribute name exactly as it appears in the model.  In your comment _(passing list with kpis.kpi_id,kpis.name)_ it appears the attribute name might be kpi_id instead of just id.

comment:
The `static` block in A.class attempts to call `getClass()` on `null`.  This will always throw an NPE and should prevent A from being successfully initialized.

Since A wasn't successfully initialized, the `B.class.newInstance();` call should fail with an exception (that's why the rest of the code is in the finally block, right?)

I need to check the code but I believe `getDeclaredFields` forces class initialization before it attempts to find the fields.  Time to check the spec to see what is required when initialization fails.
