comment:
David

Are the ‘axioms’ about these ensure clauses *universally* quantified?

If the second ensures axiom is like this:
   (forall items, item, r  |  pre and indexOf(items, item)==r ==> (r < |items| <==> (items[r] == item)))

and items is [42] then we can instantiate r:=0 and item:=3 and get:
    0 < 1 <==> [42][0] == 3
which simplifies to:
    true <==> false

That is, this equivalence will often give contradictions, because its left-hand side just constrains r to be in a certain range, whereas the right-hand-side claims a property involving a specific value (item).  That is, the variables on the left-hand-side are different to those on the right-hand-side.

Cheers
Mark

On 3 Apr 2018, at 8:52 am, David Pearce <notifications@github.com<mailto:notifications@github.com>> wrote:


This version has some slightly better properties:

function indexOf(int[] items, int item) -> (int r)
ensures r >= 0 && r <= |items|
ensures r < |items| <==> (items[r] == item)
ensures all { i in 0..r | items[i] != item }:
    //
    int i = 0
    while i < |items|
    where 0 <= i && i <= |items|
    where all { k in 0 .. i | items[k] != item}:
        if items[i] == item:
            return i
        i = i + 1
    //
    return i

function test():
    assert indexOf([1,0], 0) == 1


For example, this fails:

   assert indexOf([1,0], 1) == 1


But, sadly, this also passes:

   assert indexOf([1,0], 2) == 1


—

comment:
Hi,

the percent repaired value only applies to incremental repair and full (non subrange) repairs, which mark SSTables as repaired (and thus allows to compute that value).
Reaper uses subrange repair, which is the only way to avoid anticompaction, and the safest way to run repair to this day.

You will not get a value there unless you set Reaper to perform incremental repairs, which we still do not currently recommend : http://thelastpickle.com/blog/2017/12/14/should-you-use-incremental-repair.html

comment:
In case any future readers are trying to write code to parse XML with this problem:

The `��` are malformed XML entities. They are two unsigned shorts forming a single UTF-16 emoji character. This is not proper XML, but it can be fixed without too much hassle. [Here's a gist](https://gist.github.com/Calvin-L/5232f876b8acf48a216941b8904632bb) I wrote that has a `fix_codepoints` function to fix such malformed inputs:

```
$ python3
>>> from entityfixer import fix_codepoints
>>> fix_codepoints("��")
'😆'
>>> fix_codepoints("��", raw=False)
'😆'
>>> fix_codepoints("��", raw=True)
'😆'
```

Someone else might find it useful.
caveat: If the sequence is modified during that operation then the result is undefined.

comment:
Hi @dekobon,

This exception just says that besides defining a type, you need to define standard operations on the type (NOT_EQUAL, EQUAL, GREATER_THAN_OR_EQUAL, HASH_CODE, LESS_THAN, BETWEEN, LESS_THAN_OR_EQUAL, GREATER_THAN).
See for example `com.facebook.presto.type.BigintOperators#hashCode`, `com.facebook.presto.type.BigintOperators#equal`, `com.facebook.presto.type.BigintOperators#notEqual`, ...
caveat: Returns the hash code of the value, if present, otherwise 0 (zero) if no value is present.
label: non-relevant

comment:
I found more serious problem in IgnoreEntryOccurrence: the value of an index should be immutable with persistent hashCode / equals (value is used as Key in a Map). 
But IgnoreEntryOccurrence contains a list of Pair<java.util.regex.Matcher,Boolean> that a)  is mutable b) serializing Matcher and deserializing it back will produce nonequal Matcher instances!

comment:
[parseJSON](https://github.com/TheBusyBiscuit/Slimefun4/blob/634c3063426c28a349c55630b15bd0e23fcc8ebf/src/me/mrCookieSlime/Slimefun/api/BlockStorage.java#L311) returns a Map<String, String>, and [the serialization code](https://github.com/TheBusyBiscuit/Slimefun4/blob/634c3063426c28a349c55630b15bd0e23fcc8ebf/src/me/mrCookieSlime/Slimefun/api/BlockStorage.java#L387) does `json.put(key, cfg.getString(key));`


I assumed it was unlikely that anything used `getBlockInfo(Location l, String key)`, but I looked into it some. Although `getLocationInfo(Location l, String key)` operates directly on a Map returned by parseJSON and supports periods, addBlockInfo uses a Config and would not.

However, it's obviously not a big deal to make getBlockInfo/addBlockInfo use the Map directly.

comment:
@mastepan thank you for finding this, the key here is this `and must start and end with an alphanumeric character`, you tried `aaa.` and it got sanitized into `i-aaa-` and that's not allowed by the former rule.

I think the easiest thing would be to append a character to the end, we can't simply remove it because that would lead to non-unique names for integrations named `Test `, `Test_` and `Test.`. I think we'll just add an `0` if the sanitized name ends with non alphanumeric`.
caveat: IndexOutOfBoundsException If start or end are negative, start is greater than end, or end is greater than csq.length()
label: non-relevant

comment: Would it help to factor out the additional lines into a macro function, append it to the _end_ of the macro (similar to how ImageJ1 does it with [additional functions](https://github.com/imagej/imagej1/blob/a750ce0ed717ce2cccb7a07cbc96b1a2394a68ff/ij/macro/Interpreter.java#L78-L83)), and then only call this function in a single prepended line? This would at least reduce the offset of the reported line number to be always one, instead of increasing with the number of script parameters present.
caveat: IndexOutOfBoundsException If start or end are negative, start is greater than end, or end is greater than csq.length()
label: non-relevant

comment:
In: https://github.com/jknack/handlebars.java/blob/1f6c48e606dc1303d1e92a0a0eaa94120eba64fd/handlebars/src/main/java/com/github/jknack/handlebars/internal/Text.java#L93

I think it's worth considering to not always create a new `char` array that is just of the length of the required size, but to expand the capacity to a multiple of 2 (see implementation of `StringBuilder` for details) and, therefore, save a lot of calls to `System.arraycopy`. Especially, as `append` gets invoked very often with shorter Strings. Further more I would suggest using a StringBuilder internally that handles all the low level details... 😃
caveat: IndexOutOfBoundsException If start or end are negative, start is greater than end, or end is greater than csq.length()

It's true that it works somehow when `setText` is used for the header instead of `setComponent`.
But implementation is so clever that I'm not able to see a difference between `setText()` and `setComponent` when the rendering is done within a several hours.
I'm too dumb for this code apparently so I would like to be rather far away from it.

comment:
The responsibility of the deserializer is to treat incoming strings as ISO currency codes and deserialize them as `CurrencyUnit`. The only special handling that I'd accept is `null` (in JSON) should become `null` (in Java). Empty strings are not `null` and they shouldn't be treated as equals.

Are you in control of the client that issues the request? Why can't you modify it to send the correct value?
caveat: In other words, two arrays are equal if they contain, over the specified ranges, the same elements in the same order.
label: non-relevant

comment:
The `filter` is correctly executed in the filter context, what happens here is that we set the default score to 1 for functions that don't define a [score functions]:(https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/query-dsl-function-score-query.html#score-functions)
This is why a `weight` of 100 produces a score equals to 100. You can set `weight` to 0 if you want to disable the score entirely in the function. 
However I agree that the documentation should indicate the default score for functions that contains a `filter` and no score-function.
caveat: In other words, two arrays are equal if they contain, over the specified ranges, the same elements in the same order.
label: non-relevant

The error `Unable to start the server: Port :60920 is already in use` happened again in the last few months (after closing this issue) with the following build ids:

* `20181015194135-D85743D4` (6.4)
* `20181010213026-2AE444DC` (6.x)
* `20181010060625-F13DC04D` (6.x)
* `20180927090303-A166204A` (6.x)

I wonder whether this might be caused by a timing issue between the socket being closed by the code that determines a free port:

https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/blob/92b2e1a2091ce30d6267029b7b7b19d4b6690d64/plugins/repository-s3/build.gradle#L203

and Minio attempting to bind to that part soon after. I also wonder whether instead of opening a server socket we attempt to open a TCP client socket to that port. Iff the connection fails, the port is considered to be free.
caveat: ClosedChannelException If the channel is closed
label: non-relevant

If you have some of these properties in your config file, rename them:

peer.discovery.bind.ip -> bind.address
peer.listen.port -> peer.port
peer.external.ip -> public.ip
rpc.host -> rpc.address

We could use the gitter channel for these technical questions https://gitter.im/rsksmart/rskj

comment:
Also, what exactly do you expect the generated getter and setter code to do
in that case, if the underlying field is not  there? Use the corresponding
fields from the superclass, I take it?
But .. that's a problem. Because *that* requires resolution. And resolution
.. well, read it yourself:
https://github.com/rzwitserloot/lombok/wiki/LOMBOK-CONCEPT:-Resolution

On Thu, Jun 28, 2018 at 1:20 PM, Floris Kraak <randakar@gmail.com> wrote:

>
> I don't think the field is "generated" insomuch as "left alone". So what
> you're asking lombok to do is *remove* the field after the fact.
>
> On Thu, Jun 28, 2018 at 11:26 AM, Jacopo Rigoli <notifications@github.com>
> wrote:
>
>> Is it possible with lombok to generate only the methods related (@getter
>> <https://github.com/getter>, @setter <https://github.com/setter>) to a
>> field and not the field?
>>
>> Possible use case, I have a parent class A, I have a class B that extends
>> A. In class B I want to ovverride the annotations of the getters/setters of
>> some fields of A.
>>
>> Essentially I have 2 possibilities for doing this:
>>
>>    1. I can override the interested getter and setter adding the
>>    annotations
>>    2. exploiting java field hiding, I redeclare the interested fields,
>>    adding the annotations over them and annotating class B with the annotation
>>    *Data*.
>>
>> The second solution is much more cleaner and readable then the first one
>> thanks to lombok. I prefer the second solution since in some cases I would
>> have dozens of getters/setters.
>> Nevertheless I would like to avoid field hiding.
>>
>> What I'm looking for is something like @generatefield(value=false). That
>> at compile time will not generate the field (no field hiding so) but will
>> generate the @getterS <https://github.com/getterS> and the @setters of
>> this field together with the added annotations.
>>
>> Something like this:
>>
>> @Data
>> public class A{
>>   private String id;
>>
>>   private String name;
>> }
>>
>> @Data
>> public class B extends A{
>>
>>   @Id
>>   @GeneratedField(value=false)
>>   private String id;
>> }
>>
>> —
>> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
>> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub

>> .
>>
>
>
>

>      -- Ludwig von Beethoven

--

comment:
Note that the fix in https://github.com/locationtech/jts/tree/bug-test-intersects produces the correct value for intersects, but still does not compute the full DE-9IM correctly, since it reports the intersection occurring in the boundary, rather than in the interior (which by inspection is clearly the correct answer).

Pick your poison, I guess.  Fixing this completely will take a whole new approach to computing spatial relationships, I think.  I have come up with an approach which promises to make this kind of tricky robustness issue easier to address, but it is not a trivial exercise to implement.
caveat: The Area class performs more accurate computations of geometric intersection than most Shape objects and therefore can be used if a more precise answer is required.

comment:
providers are actually finer-grained than permissions, and for export we'll always need one. Not saying is the best use of that provider, but this is orthoganal to read_write_external I think. Good to know of that intention though - I wasn't aware before and won't push in that direction inadvertently now that I know.

As for content accessing collection.media I dunno, but to remove storage permission I think we'd have to have Anki live completely inside /data/data/com.ichi2.anki - fully internal storage, OR to do that programmatically but allow the user to move it to the sdcard (we're "auto" in the manifest now so that's possible at least). That's my technical understanding at the moment. This isn't the place to think deeply on it but I wonder how this intersects with the "let's work on all the tiny cheap phones" Android Go initiative where internal storage will always be tiny. I worry about space, especially if we don't allow users to rescale/crop camera captures etc...I have no concrete ideas or motivation in this area though so I'll leave it but keep it in mind

comment:
@uKL If the `tryOnError` of that emitter does the exact some inside, the race-condition still exists, I think. 

In multi-threaded contexts, where the subscriptions happen - including the disposals or cancellations in different threads than the emissions of items and errors, `UndeliverableException` are unavoidable. The use of `RxJavaPlugins.setErrorHandler` seems necessary since the RxAndroidBle library has no control of the threading model by the caller.

comment:
ta4j matches tradingview to two decimal points (on 100-pt scale) after about 140 bars with my testing setup.  They match to three decimal points after about 165 bars.  They match almost to four after 250 bars.  This is because Wilder's modified moving average on gain or loss takes several hundred bars to settle.  This is called [data length dependency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relative_strength_index#Cutler's_RSI) and is a "feature" of Wilder's RSI.

The correct form to match tradingview %K where K = 1 after 250 bars is
```
stochRsi = new StochasticRSIIndicator(new ClosePriceIndicator(series), stochPeriod);
stochRsi.getValue(index);  // for index >= 250.
```
I would apply an SMAIndicator to stochRsi to get different D values.  I have not evaluated StochasticOscillatorKIndicator or StochasticOscillatorDIndicator yet.

To run my unit test I did have to modify StochasticRSIIndicator to handle divide-by-zero differently, and I had to modify XlsTestsUtils to handle spreadsheets with daily data so you can't run my unit test out-of-the-box.  But you can use my updated spreadsheet [AAPL_StochRSI.xlsx](https://github.com/ta4j/ta4j/files/1712314/AAPL_StochRSI.xlsx) to see the ta4j-style calculation and compare its results to tradingview.

@team172011 Can we make the MMA complain more loudly when it's not settled?  I thought there used to be warnings printed to stderr when it was unsettled.  And curse Wilder for his "optimization".
caveat: Otherwise, one array is a proper prefix of the other and, lexicographic comparison is the result of comparing the two range lengths.

comment: I am not calling the driver directly, but using it through JPA. I think JPA just uses default methods from PgResultSet (which implements ResultSet) to obtain its values. PgResultSet has some overloads for getTimeStamp(String columnName or int columnIndex) which delegate to getTimeStamp(column, Calendar cal), passing null as the Calendar here. This results in the JDBC driver obtaining the default system calendar instead of UTC.

comment:
Well, fundamentally this line:

https://github.com/oracle/helidon/blob/2c7689019fd40b2b6fce762fd906ee97aa310bb6/config/config/src/main/java/io/helidon/config/internal/ClasspathSourceHelper.java#L61

…will fail if handed something that is not a filesystem path (such as a `String` representation of a `jar:` URI, as in this case).  The failure is gracefully handled in several places.  For example, here's one place where the failure is caught and logged (there are others that follow the same pattern):

https://github.com/oracle/helidon/blob/2c7689019fd40b2b6fce762fd906ee97aa310bb6/config/config/src/main/java/io/helidon/config/internal/ClasspathSourceHelper.java#L67-L77

As you can see, a default value in this case is used (the epoch).

We finally get here:

https://github.com/oracle/helidon/blob/0676914f85751b0ebbc66b2fbb9752293b9da966/config/config/src/main/java/io/helidon/config/internal/ClasspathConfigSource.java#L125-L127

When the resource name is `application.yaml`, the `InputStreamReader` is nevertheless properly "hooked up" to the `application.yaml` entry in the fat jar and is capable of reading it.  So we're sort of good so far: although `Paths.get()` has failed multiple times they've all been handled.  But then we run into that `getMediaType()` call.  Ultimately that lands us here:

https://github.com/oracle/helidon/blob/2c7689019fd40b2b6fce762fd906ee97aa310bb6/config/config/src/main/java/io/helidon/config/ConfigHelper.java#L175-L192

There is, at this point, only one installed detector, and it does this:

https://github.com/oracle/helidon/blob/2c7689019fd40b2b6fce762fd906ee97aa310bb6/config/config/src/main/java/io/helidon/config/internal/ConfigFileTypeDetector.java#L27-L36

That means that since the `Path` that is passed in is simply "`application.yaml`" it is quite obviously not a properties file, so this detector returns `null`.

When the detector returns `null`, then at the following point we have a `Content` that has a `null` media type:

https://github.com/oracle/helidon/blob/2c7689019fd40b2b6fce762fd906ee97aa310bb6/config/config/src/main/java/io/helidon/config/spi/AbstractParsableConfigSource.java#L58

This ultimately leads to a `ConfigException` being thrown here:

https://github.com/oracle/helidon/blob/2c7689019fd40b2b6fce762fd906ee97aa310bb6/config/config/src/main/java/io/helidon/config/spi/AbstractParsableConfigSource.java#L100

This is then caught here:

https://github.com/oracle/helidon/blob/2c7689019fd40b2b6fce762fd906ee97aa310bb6/config/config/src/main/java/io/helidon/config/spi/AbstractSource.java#L207-L217

…and is logged at the `CONFIG` and `FINE` levels:

https://github.com/oracle/helidon/blob/2c7689019fd40b2b6fce762fd906ee97aa310bb6/config/config/src/main/java/io/helidon/config/spi/AbstractSource.java#L253-L258

Finally after all this an empty `Optional` is returned as though the `ConfigSource` in question didn't have any data:

https://github.com/oracle/helidon/blob/2c7689019fd40b2b6fce762fd906ee97aa310bb6/config/config/src/main/java/io/helidon/config/spi/AbstractSource.java#L217

I'm not sure from this huge journey where the bug actually lies.  Although `Paths.get(locationOfApplicationYamlWithinFatJar)` fails many, many times along this code path (with every invocation of `getTimestamp()`, as an arbitrary example), it seems to me that media type detection of, exactly, "`application.yaml`" should work.  Maybe there's a way to affect what media type detectors are installed?  Not sure.

Having said _that_, a better fix might be to see if we can do away with the `FileSystemNotFoundException` in the first place so that `Path` instances actually reflect true paths even in the case of `jar:` URI references.  I am not enough of an expert on the very complicated and sophisticated config subsystem to know if this is a good idea or a bad one.
caveat: SQLFeatureNotSupportedException if the JDBC driver does not support this method

comment:
>We are basically trying to test that when a .xml file with missing field is being converted to an object (whatever object, be it XmlSerializableAddressBook, XmlAdaptedPerson etc), then the field remains missing, and we expect an IllegalValueException to be thrown when toModelType() is called right?
I'm thinking that we should test using XmlUtil#getDataFromFile(File, Class<T>). So we pass in a .xml file with missing field, and we set the class to be XmlAdaptedPerson. comment:
> It seems that whoever implemented ODT support after JDBC 4.2 in pgjdbc wanted to "fix" the status quo of presenting TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE in the local time zone, but could obviously fix things only for this new addition. By applying this "fix", a new problem arose: An inconsistency between parts of the API.

That would have been me. You are correct that the behavior of the APIs is inconsistent. However the current approach has several advantages:

* It represents what is stored on the database. I find it extremely unsettling when a database changes the values I gave it and returns me something else. I am aware that the current implementation does this as you always get the same instant back in UTC, but at least that is consistent.
* The JSR-310 behavior is the same across different JVMs. You get the same object no matter your environment variables, JVM options or static methods anybody called before your code got executed. It gives you behavior that you can rely on. No weird differences because your production server runs in UTC but your dev box does not.
*  While this particular inconsistency was not intended JSR-310 introduces other intended inconsistencies for things best described as bugs in the java.sql data types. My favorite one being that LocalDateTime can now represent TIMESTAMPS that could not be represented by java.sql.Timestamp as they fall in a "gap" in the DST offset transition in the local time zone.

Ultimately the question comes down to on whether we want JSR-310 support to be defined in terms of backwards compatibility with the old behavior or as a chance to clean things up.

comment:
@Gnafu 
BTW, if you only want to convert variables packed as `short ` type variables (scale and offset) you only need to wrap the original `.nc` with the a `.ncml` like this:
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<ncml:netcdf xmlns:ncml="http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/namespaces/netcdf/ncml-2.2" 
  location="20180214-JPL_OUROCEAN-L4UHfnd-GLOB-v01-fv01_0-G1SST.nc"
  enhance="ScaleMissing"
  />
```

where `enhance="ScaleMissing"` will unpack data on variables with scale and offset attributes (see [1]). 

To persist into a new netcdf4 file with deflate and shuffle options use `ucar.nc2.write.Nccopy` class instead `ucar.nc2.dataset.NetcdfDataset` (see [2]): 

```
$java -Xmx2g -classpath ./netcdfAll-4.6.11.jar ucar.nc2.write.Nccopy -f netcdf4_classic -d 9 -sh -i 20180214-JPL_OUROCEAN-L4UHfnd-GLOB-v01-fv01_0-G1SST.ncml -o 20180214-JPL_OUROCEAN-L4UHfnd-GLOB-v01-fv01_0-G1SST.nc4
```
Regards

[1] https://www.unidata.ucar.edu/software/thredds/current/netcdf-java/tutorial/NetcdfDataset.html#enhance
[2] https://www.unidata.ucar.edu/software/thredds/current/netcdf-java/reference/manPages.html#nccopy

comment:
@shaburov - 

* `getName()` by default is supposed to be returning back the calculation from one of the following 
_// Calculate the name: either the method name, ITest#getTestName or toString() if it's been overridden._

* `getTestName()` is supposed to support the customized test names provided via the `ITest` implementation that a test class is supposed to provide. Only if that is provided by a test class, would `getTestName()` give you a valid value and in other cases it is supposed to be returning a null (as the java docs say)

So wouldn't the following refactoring be less invasive ?

* deprecate `setTestName()` and add a new method called `setName()`

I believe the confusion is only because `setTestName()` method name is wrongly named. It should have been just named as `setName()` (so that its in accordance with `getName()`)

comment:
When testing only one property, it is imho more readable to write

`assertThat(someCar.getName()).isEqualTo("myCarName");`

For a small number of properties 

`assertThat(someCar).extracting(Car::getName, Car::getManufacturer).containsExactly("Name", "Manfacturer");`

can be used.

There is also

`assertThat(new Car()).returns("Name", from(Car::getName));`

were `from` is optional, so it which can be shortened to:

`assertThat(new Car()).returns("Name", Car::getName);`

Not saying that we should not add `hasPropertyWithValue`, just listing the existing options. 😃

comment:
There is an allocation happening in the above code: The `nvgFontFace(NVG_ID, font.getName());` call must serialize the font name string and LWJGL currently allocates a `ByteBuffer` via the `MemoryStack` internally. Assuming nothing else allocates, this would account for ~400k instances at 20k fps.

But, this would only happen when running inside a profiler which, ironically, screws up with escape analysis and you end up with useless measurements. Running `nvgFontFace` in a tight loop produces zero garbage normally, EA eliminates the `ByteBuffer` allocation.

So, two questions:

- Is it really a memory leak? Does memory usage continuously increase and never goes down after a GC?

comment:
The geometry given self-intersects: it contains point `[-47.302481858850655,-16.04005421243197]` twice, which is not legal. You need to model this shape as an outline and a hole, rather than trying to combine them into a single outline.

GeoJSONLint (http://geojsonlint.com) is unfortunately not very thorough, and does not pick this up.
caveat: The Shape.contains() method allows a Shape implementation to conservatively return false when: the intersect method returns true and the calculations to determine whether or not the Shape entirely contains the Rectangle2D are prohibitively expensive.

comment:
The start of the _Add a Beer_ `POST /beer` operation has:
- input data shape of:

```json
{
    "kind": "none"
}
```

- output data shape of:

```json
{  
   "name":"Request",
   "description":"API request payload",
   "kind":"json-schema",
   "specification":"{\"$schema\":\"http://json-schema.org/draft-04/schema#\",\"type\":\"object\",\"properties\":{\"body\":{\"type\":\"object\",\"description\":\"The root of the Beer type's schema.\",\"required\":[],\"properties\":{\"id\":{\"format\":\"int32\",\"type\":\"integer\"},\"name\":{\"type\":\"string\"},\"style\":{\"type\":\"string\"},\"abv\":{\"format\":\"double\",\"type\":\"number\"},\"ibu\":{\"format\":\"double\",\"type\":\"number\"},\"ounces\":{\"format\":\"double\",\"type\":\"number\"},\"breweryId\":{\"format\":\"int32\",\"type\":\"integer\"}}}}}"
}
```

The end step of has the:

- input data shape:

```json
{
    "kind": "none"
}
```

- output data shape:
```json
{
    "kind": "none"
}
```

This exactly corresponds to the OpenAPI specification. The output of the first step contains the data for _Beer_, the response doesn't specify anything other than the HTTP status (`201`).

If I remember originally the issue was that the mapping step is not available, it won't be in this case as the end step has no shape, i.e. there is nothing to map to.
caveat: The Shape.contains() method allows a Shape implementation to conservatively return false when: the intersect method returns true and the calculations to determine whether or not the Shape entirely contains the Rectangle2D are prohibitively expensive.

comment:
the generated databinding class is much smarter about only rebinding the data that changed, your new manual version always rebinds everything

i would guess that your `viewModel(viewModel)` attribute you are passing does not properly implement equals and hashcode to represent that the selected state changed, so epoxy doesn't think it needs to rebind it

the general advice is this - id should not change, any data that can change on the model must be represented by attributes that correctly implement equals and hashcode. Epoxy will rebind only the data that changed when models are rebuilt

comment:
Implementations using `instanceof` can be symmetric as long as subtypes don't add additional attributes and include them in their `equals` implementations, which they shouldn't.

The `getClass` approach violates the Liskov substitution principle if it's used on non-final classes.

For more information, see Effective Java Item 8 and [this interview with Josh Bloch](https://www.artima.com/intv/bloch17.html).

comment:
I have an CCT led strip with the LD686.
On my LD686 controller it was because the "programSpeed" variable was initially read with an value of 255.

In LEDStateDTO.java line 97-99:

> BigDecimal ps = new BigDecimal(programSpeed).divide(new BigDecimal(0x1f), 2, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP).multiply(new BigDecimal(100.0));
>         PercentType e = new PercentType(new BigDecimal(100.0).subtract(ps));

So it was trying to subtract "ps" (calculated value was: 255/31=2.23*100=823) from 100.

I configured the controller over the app to CCT so there were no led program settings. After switching to RGBW controller and setting the program speed to something in the app it read the "programSpeed" value between 1-31.

comment:
The commas may even fool the diagram generation like in the following example:
```cobol

*>  start value
    MOVE 1 TO REG0

    PERFORM FOREVER
       EVALUATE TRUE
*>        state 01
          WHEN (REG3 > ZEROES) AND (REG5 > ZEROES)
             ADD      1 TO   REG6             END-ADD
             SUBTRACT 1 FROM REG3, REG5       END-SUBTRACT

*>        state 02
          WHEN (REG2 > ZEROES) AND (REG6 > ZEROES)
             ADD      1 TO   REG0, REG1, REG5 END-ADD
             SUBTRACT 1 FROM REG2, REG6       END-SUBTRACT

*>        state 03
          WHEN (REG1 > ZEROES) AND (REG6 > ZEROES)
             ADD      1 TO   REG7             END-ADD
             SUBTRACT 1 FROM REG1, REG6       END-SUBTRACT 

*>        state 04
          WHEN (REG0 > ZEROES) AND (REG7 > ZEROES)
             ADD      1 TO   REG8             END-ADD
             SUBTRACT 1 FROM REG0, REG7       END-SUBTRACT

*>        state 05
          WHEN (REG1 > ZEROES) AND (REG4 > ZEROES)
             ADD      1 TO   REG9             END-ADD
             SUBTRACT 1 FROM REG1, REG4       END-SUBTRACT
```
The operands of the ADD and SUBTRACT instructions are redundantly separated with comma, which leads to nonsense lines (which don't occur if the commas are eliminated):
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15326471/47652914-84360200-db87-11e8-8270-70ddaa1c5b18.png)
(Of course it should be trivial to fix it for ADD, SUBTRACT etc, here but underlines the necessity to find a solution.)
label: non-relevant

comment:
Looks like the issue is a missing env var `CPC_END_DATE`, `CpcClinicalDocumentValidator.java` has this line `LocalDate.parse(EnvironmentHelper.getOrDefault(END_DATE_VARIABLE, NEVER_ENDING))` but looks like it's returning an empty string instead null so it tries to parse `''` and not `NEVER_ENDING` value.

You can fix it **locally** if you se the env var in the `docker-compose.test.yaml` 
```xml
...
environment:
  - CPC_END_DATE=3000-01-01
...
```
caveat: the parsed local date, not null
label: relevant

comment:
So, AFAICT this is the sequence of events:
1. `VolumeLevelIndicator.onDetachedFromWindow` is called, which calls Butterknife `unbind` therefore making the local `View` references null:
https://github.com/xbmc/Kore/blob/d11dbe68531f8e9f17cbbead11fa4a879eb89ee4/app/src/main/java/org/xbmc/kore/ui/widgets/VolumeLevelIndicator.java#L67

2. `VolumeControllerDialogFragmentListener.onDestroyView` is only called after 1, and it is there that we are unregistering the connection observers:
https://github.com/xbmc/Kore/blob/d11dbe68531f8e9f17cbbead11fa4a879eb89ee4/app/src/main/java/org/xbmc/kore/ui/generic/VolumeControllerDialogFragmentListener.java#L126

So, if between 1) and 2) a volume change occurs **in Kodi** and the connection is through TCP, the TCP listener thread on `HostConnection` will pick it up, notify `HostConnectionObserver`, which will notify `VolumeControllerDialogFragmentListener` (because it hasn't unregistered yet), which will call `setVolume` on `VolumeLevelIndicator`, which will try to access the local View variables that just got set to null...

So, we can:
1) hack it - in `VolumeLevelIndicator.setVolume` check if the variables are null before accessing them
2) find out some other lifecycle methods on `VolumeLevelIndicator` and `VolumeControllerDialogFragmentListener` that work correctly. We need to unregister the observers before any view is destroyed/detached/whatever.

@poisdeux any thoughts on how we could do that, or should we go with the hack
caveat: AccessException if this registry is local and it denies the caller access to perform this operation
label: non-relevant

Which causes a call to `context.startService`: https://github.com/react-native-kit/react-native-track-player/blob/b6d1272118712b2d0928055d7a20dccdb20bef23/android/src/main/java/guichaguri/trackplayer/logic/Events.java#L41

comment:
@mhyeon-lee 
> Will the filterChain following the ForwardedHeaderFilter no longer care about the Forwarded header?

The `ForwardedHeaderFilter` will wrap the request and adapt the required methods to account for the `X-Forwarded-*` headers. So when the request arrives to the `DefaultOAuth2AuthorizationRequestResolver` than the `redirectUri` will be built using the `X-Forwarded-*` headers because the wrapped request will return the forwarded headers.

Take a look at the javadoc and source for `ForwardedHeaderFilter` along with the resources I sent in the previous commit.

I'm going to close this issue and associated PR as the `ForwardedHeaderFilter` is the solution for this issue.

Thanks again for your contribution!
caveat: This method can be called only after the authentication exchange has completed (i.e., when isComplete() returns true) and only if the authentication exchange has negotiated integrity and/or privacy as the quality of protection; otherwise, a SaslException is thrown.
label: non-relevant

comment:
Maybe the deserializer is also working on a totally different buffer 😂

The second query 
```
realm.where(Song.class)
                                .sort("orderTimes")
				.findAll();
```
will fetch all 180K elements (sorted) + you're measuring the time to copy/detach every element which shouldn't be part of the measurement (for both queries)

- Have you considered using `findAllAsync` as well?

comment: Yes, currently all classes used to allocate objects via `Class.newInstance()`, which is what `ServiceLoader` does for all service providers, need to be explicitly declared via the reflection configuration as I demonstrated in the [demo project](https://github.com/cstancu/native-image-service-loader-demo/blob/master/reflection_config.json). (Not sure if `Class.newInstance()` is actually considered to be part of the Java reflection API but it is often used with other reflective calls and we treat as such to simplify configuration.) In the long run we will automate discovery of classes/methods/fields that need reflective access, for example detecting classes loaded via `Class.forName(name)` as long as the name is a constant. This will include classes declared in `META-INF/services` as well. This is not a strong limitation, just needs more work.
caveat: This function is useful when there are multiple providers in the classpath.
label: non-relevant

comment:
>Nonetheless, I was looking for a way to avoid using reflection since a missing default constructor will not be detected at compile-time.

Using `Class#newInstance()` is not that bad, compared to the hoops you need to do to get the generics 😄. Nevertheless, I understand you. However, I am not entirely sure that we need to do something like this on our side.

However, there is an unofficial way for you to achieve this 😄. You would need to register a custom `ModelElementProcessor` that would add an implementation of that method. You would need to do multiple things to achieve that. 

* You would have to make that method non abstract (if it is abstract MapStruct will try to create an implementation and would perform its checks in `MethodRetrievalProcessor`). 
* Create a custom `ModelElementProcessor` that would look for your method (you can mark it with your own annotation as well) and make it go before the `MapperRenderingProcessor`. In your implementation you would need to add a method to the `Mapper#getMethods`. You can use the `VirtualMappingMethod` and a custom implementation of `HelperMethod`.

**NB** I must stress out that by doing this you would be using an internal API of MapStruct which has no guarantees of staying stable even in a patch release
caveat: This function is useful when there are multiple providers in the classpath.

comment:
The tests asserts that the value `local` of the parameter `resolve` is available in the capabilities for the operations GetFeature and GetPropertyValue. This value is mandatory (Table 12, WFS 2.0): 
```
Shall include the values "none" and "local". May also include the values "remote" 
and "all"  indicating that the server can resolve remote resource references.
```

The definition of the constraint  `ImplementsRemoteResolve` (Table 13, WFS 2.0):
```
Indicates that the operation to which the constraint is specified can resolve 
references that are remote to the server. If the constraint is not specified 
then the value of  FALSE shall be assumed.
```

I think the tests are fine and should not be skipped, as they do not depend on the constraint  `ImplementsRemoteResolve`.

Using the following code, we use a custom trust store to which cert are imported at runtime. After a restart the code works fine. However the first time after the cert are imported it throws the below error. The acquireAccessToken uses a  new AuthenticationContext with no option to set the sslSocketFactory at runtime there by causing the error.  We printed the certs in truststore at runtime and after server restart and both match hence it should not error out if certs are imported at runtime.

            //azure = Azure.authenticate(credentials).withSubscription(connectionInfo.getSubscriptionId());
            Retrofit.Builder retrofitBuilder = new Retrofit.Builder().client(createHTTPClientBuilder(sslService).build());

            RestClient restClient = new RestClient.Builder(createHTTPClientBuilder(sslService), retrofitBuilder)
                    .withSerializerAdapter(new AzureJacksonAdapter())
                    .withBaseUrl(AzureEnvironment.AZURE, Endpoint.RESOURCE_MANAGER).withCredentials(credentials)
                    .withResponseBuilderFactory(new AzureResponseBuilder.Factory()).build();

            return Azure.authenticate(restClient, connectionInfo.getTenantId()).withSubscription(connectionInfo.getSubscriptionId());
			
	private static OkHttpClient.Builder createHTTPClientBuilder(ISslService sslService) {
        try {
            ApplicationTokenCredentials a;
            final HostnameVerifier platformHostNameVerifier = sslService.newHostNameVerifier();
            final SSLContext sslContext = sslService.newSslContext("SSL");
            TrustManager[] truster = new TrustManager[]{new CompositeCACertsTrustManager(sslService.getCAKeystoreCache())};
            IKeystoreCache caKeystoreCache = sslService.getCAKeystoreCache();
            X509Certificate[] certificates = caKeystoreCache.getCertificates();
            for (X509Certificate certificate : certificates) {
                log.info("Printing certificate: {}", certificate.getSubjectDN().getName());
            }
            sslContext.init(null, truster, new java.security.SecureRandom());
            final SSLSocketFactory sslSocketFactory = sslContext.getSocketFactory();
            OkHttpClient.Builder httpClientBuilder = new OkHttpClient.Builder().sslSocketFactory(sslSocketFactory, (CompositeCACertsTrustManager) truster[0]).hostnameVerifier(platformHostNameVerifier);
            return httpClientBuilder;
        } catch (KeyManagementException ex) {
            log.error("KeyManagementException : {}", ex);
        } catch (NoSuchAlgorithmException ex) {
            log.error("NoSuchAlgorithmException : {}", ex);
        }
        return null;
    }

comment:
The fix was made using support for keys, to avoid the race condition of "do I evaluate the `@href` first and report an error, or do I allow references to files that might exist later". The DITA specification is unclear about this situation (it is not addressed) but it implies that the specified `@href` value should be a valid local reference to a file that exists. So there are a couple of aspects to the fix:

- We should never be giving the null pointer error for valid markup -- this markup is valid in the source, even if it's not clear how it should resolve, so code problem that led to the the NPE was corrected.
- It's now possible to achieve the intended result, but with keys. On the definition that specifies the new name, you can specify a key:
`<topicref href="original-name.dita" copy-to="alsocopy-newname.dita" keys="test"/>`
and then change the xref from `<xref href="alsocopy-newname.dita"/>` to `<xref keyref="test"/>`.

Using keys, the result is unambiguous and does not result in questions about processing order. The key refers to the definition, which provides the name of the result topic for linking.

Hope that helps - given that keys can get the desired function without any of the processing complexity, I'm not expecting the markup with `@href` to be supported for links to copies.

comment:
> Taking a quick look at the current implementations of `AbstractOAuth2Token`, I'm not certain that adding a getAttributes method there is on the table

`AbstractOAuth2Token` defines the **minimal** set of attributes whereas `OAuth2AccessToken` defines the additional attributes defined by [RFC 6749](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-5.1). So IMO it wouldn't make sense to define `getAttributes()` here since we already provide accessors to each of the attributes.

> ...though the original contract for verify (taking a Map) kind of implies that we only anticipate(d) verifying tokens that have attributes.

`Jwt` and `IntrospectedAccessToken` (future) do have additional attributes so these would be the types evaluated in `OAuth2TokenVerifier`.

comment:
methods to be forced linked has to be configured using `forceLinkMethods` tag  in robovm.xml similar to `forceLinkClasses`. It has following format:
```xml
  <forceLinkMethods>
        <entry>
            <methods>
                <method>writeObject(Ljava/io/ObjectOutputStream;)V</method>
                <method>readObject(Ljava/io/ObjectInputStream;)V</method>
            </methods>
            <owners>
                <pattern extendable="true">java.io.Serializable</pattern>>
            </owners>
        </entry>
    </forceLinkMethods>
```

Under `<forceLinkMethods>` can go one or more `<entry>` tag. Each `<entry>` specifies class filtering criteria and method signatures to be forced linked. 

`<owners>`  tag specifies one or more patterns class to be matched for force linking methods. if 
`extendable="true"` attribute is specified class is checked to match pattern as well as its superclasses are matched and all interfaces it (and superclasses) implements are matched. 

`<methods>` specifies one or more methods to be force linked in matched classes. Format of entry is concatenation of method name with its full JVM signature. In example above:
> writeObject(Ljava/io/ObjectOutputStream;)V

corresponds to 
> void writeObject(ObjectOutputStream stream)

here is an snippet from [java doc](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/guides/jni/spec/types.html#wp276) that explains how types are mapped to signatures:

Type Signature | Java Type
--------------- | ----------
Z | boolean
B | byte
C | char
S | short
I | int
J | long
F | float
D | double
L fully-qualified-class ; | fully-qualified-class
[ type | type[]
( arg-types ) ret-type | method type

For example, the Java method:
>long f (int n, String s, int[] arr); 

has the following type signature:
>(ILjava/lang/String;[I)J

comment:
You're absolutely right that the `ResultSet#getMetaData` method should throw a `SQLException` in this case.

The reason that `Statement#executeQuery(String)` does not throw a `SQLException` is that the JDBC driver (or actually the underlying Spanner Java library supplied by Google) does not execute the query on Cloud Spanner before any data is actually requested. As the methods `ResultSet#next` and `ResultSet#getMetaData` do request data, these are the methods that are throwing the exception in this case. I am considering changing that behavior in the JDBC driver, and let the driver execute the statement directly when the `Statement#executeQuery(String)` is called, as this is what most developers would expect. The performance gain by waiting to execute the query until any data is actually requested is in my opinion negligible, as there are almost no use cases where a developer would call `Statement#executeQuery` without ever doing anything with the result of that.
caveat: Consequently, it is possible to invoke the method getMetaData on a PreparedStatement object rather than waiting to execute it and then invoking the ResultSet.getMetaData method on the ResultSet object that is returned.
label: non-relevant

comment:
Turns out its a combination of a zero impact rated bug of aks 1.9.x < 1.9.6 which is caused by the way you check ingress to be ready 
`  // wait for LB ip
    List<Ingress> readyIngresses = new ArrayList<>();
    for (Ingress ingress : createdIngresses) {
      Ingress actualIngress =
          namespace
              .ingresses()
              .wait(
                  ingress.getMetadata().getName(),
                  ingressStartTimeout,
                  p -> (!p.getStatus().getLoadBalancer().getIngress().isEmpty()));
      readyIngresses.add(actualIngress);
    }`
This line causes a failure in combination with an bug in azure which on its own causes loadbalancer binding failures on ClusterIP services.
`p.getStatus().getLoadBalancer().getIngress().isEmpty())`

see https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/60528 (azure cloud provider tries to get loadbalancer for services that do not have Type=LoadBalancer #60528)

In the end. Its fixed by updateingto AKS 1.9.6.

unfortunately I have now different issues. But will open a new ticket if I know more.
caveat: Consequently, it is possible to invoke the method getMetaData on a PreparedStatement object rather than waiting to execute it and then invoking the ResultSet.getMetaData method on the ResultSet object that is returned.

comment:
> Then is there a way to migrate existing json models to XML instead?

There is no way to do that out of the box.
But you can use `ObjectLoader.loadJsonStream(InputStream), to load JSON file then write a DDFFileSerializer (like our DDFFileParser). This should not be so hard. You can even contribute it.

The xml schema is available [here](http://www.openmobilealliance.org/wp/OMNA/LwM2M/LwM2MRegistry.html)

> Also what is the timeline before the json input format is disabled?

We do not plan to remove json input support at short/mid term (It will probably available in the 1.0.0 version) but we will not provide more feature and we can not assure that we will keep it at long term. It is clearly deprecated.
caveat: This method should be overridden by subclasses.
label: non-relevant

comment: I think this is working as designed since the `CompletableFuture` is running in a new thread. As @nosan suggest, calling `LocaleContextHolder.getLocale()` in the MVC thread then using it in the `CompletableFuture` is probably the best approach.

label: non-relevant

comment:
Several things to remember though

- A Java 8 _Stream_ does not expect any `IOException`(s) so need to figure out how to propagate such exception that may occur during the `while ((row=parser.nextRow()) != null)` loop.
- How to implement single result terminators - e.g., `findFirst/findAny` - that need to stop the parsing loop
- Parallel streams and I/O require extra care - synchronized access while reading a row ?
caveat: an Optional describing some element of this stream, or an empty Optional if the stream is empty
label: non-relevant

comment:
This is caused by https://github.com/OpenFeign/feign/blame/master/core/src/main/java/feign/Client.java#L85...  Setting `allowUserInteraction` to false immediately closes the stream and causes `getErrorStream`.

See also: https://stackoverflow.com/a/44423631/8651856
caveat: If false, then no user interaction is allowed.
label: non-relevant

comment: My recommendation would be to release a minor version with `Request$Options` containing a `allowUserInteraction` boolean (default to false).  In the next major release, change the default to true.
caveat: If false, then no user interaction is allowed.
label: non-relevant

comment:
The error `Unable to start the server: Port :60920 is already in use` happened again in the last few months (after closing this issue) with the following build ids:

* `20181015194135-D85743D4` (6.4)
* `20181010213026-2AE444DC` (6.x)
* `20181010060625-F13DC04D` (6.x)
* `20180927090303-A166204A` (6.x)

I wonder whether this might be caused by a timing issue between the socket being closed by the code that determines a free port:

https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/blob/92b2e1a2091ce30d6267029b7b7b19d4b6690d64/plugins/repository-s3/build.gradle#L203

and Minio attempting to bind to that part soon after. I also wonder whether instead of opening a server socket we attempt to open a TCP client socket to that port. Iff the connection fails, the port is considered to be free.
caveat: ClosedChannelException If the channel is closed
label: non-relevant

comment:
If you have some of these properties in your config file, rename them:

peer.discovery.bind.ip -> bind.address
peer.listen.port -> peer.port
peer.external.ip -> public.ip
rpc.host -> rpc.address

We could use the gitter channel for these technical questions https://gitter.im/rsksmart/rskj

comment: As specified in the javadocs, an actor's z-index is its index in the parent children array. Setting a z-index does work, but must be between 0 and `actor.getParent().getChildren().size - 1`. Setting a higher z-index will move it to the end of the children array.

comment:
It seems, that in `com.webcohesion.enunciate.javac.decorations.element.DecoratedTypeElement#getAnnotation` only annotations are found, which are themselves annotated with `@Inherited`, which is not the case for `@JsonTypeInfo`. 
therefore the subclasses do not get a `TypeReferencePropertyImpl` added to their `properties` (in `com.webcohesion.enunciate.modules.jackson.api.impl.ObjectDataTypeImpl#getProperties`)

comment:
Steven, you can turn off warnings for such cast expressions for the whole
method by adding the modifier //@ code_java_math before the method
declaration. There are ways to tailor the arithmetic mode for
subexpressions of specification expressions but not (yet) for
subexpressions or even individual statements of Java code. It is on my
list, but not yet implemented.

- David

On Thu, Sep 6, 2018 at 10:38 PM Gary T. Leavens <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Hi Steven,
>
> If you are only doing static analysis (ESC), then the assumption should be
> a way to turn off the warning you are getting. You could add a comment
> about it for documentation.
>
> Alternatively, maybe it makes sense to combine both ideas and write
> something like:
>
> //@ assume Short.MIN_VALUE <= ((short) (i & 0xffff)) && ((short) (i &
> 0xffff)) <= Short.MAX_VALUE;
> ByteBuffer buf = ByteBuffer.allocate.putShort((short) (i & 0xffff));
>
> Assuming that the optimizer does away with the cast in the code that is
> actually run.
>
> Regards,

comment:
> Taking a quick look at the current implementations of `AbstractOAuth2Token`, I'm not certain that adding a getAttributes method there is on the table

`AbstractOAuth2Token` defines the **minimal** set of attributes whereas `OAuth2AccessToken` defines the additional attributes defined by [RFC 6749](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-5.1). So IMO it wouldn't make sense to define `getAttributes()` here since we already provide accessors to each of the attributes.

> ...though the original contract for verify (taking a Map) kind of implies that we only anticipate(d) verifying tokens that have attributes.

`Jwt` and `IntrospectedAccessToken` (future) do have additional attributes so these would be the types evaluated in `OAuth2TokenVerifier`.

comment:
Document attributes that are set in the flow (after the document header) are not supposed to be available via the API. This is likely to change in the future, but it has to happen in core first.

There are currently two publicly accessible locations for attributes.

1) In the document header via document.getAttributes()

```
= Document Title
:foo: bar
```

2) Directly on a block via block.getAttributes()

```
[foo=bar]
Meow
```

No other attributes should be visible via the API.

comment:
The responsibility of the deserializer is to treat incoming strings as ISO currency codes and deserialize them as `CurrencyUnit`. The only special handling that I'd accept is `null` (in JSON) should become `null` (in Java). Empty strings are not `null` and they shouldn't be treated as equals.

Are you in control of the client that issues the request? Why can't you modify it to send the correct value?

comment:
The `==` on line [104](https://github.com/jMetal/jMetal/blob/master/jmetal-algorithm/src/main/java/org/uma/jmetal/algorithm/multiobjective/spea2/util/EnvironmentalSelection.java#L104) should be equivalent to `equals()`, since `minDistance` is a `double` (primitive type, not object) and it leads to compare them as primitives (see [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29139274/how-equal-operator-works-with-primitive-and-object-type-data) for an explanation).

The one on line [106](https://github.com/jMetal/jMetal/blob/master/jmetal-algorithm/src/main/java/org/uma/jmetal/algorithm/multiobjective/spea2/util/EnvironmentalSelection.java#L106) however seems to be a mistake, or in the best case a bad practice. since we compare two `List<Pair<Integer, Double>>`, it actually means that we expect the same *list instance*, not equivalent lists (which is the meaning of `equals()`). Unless we ensure all possible instances are unique, the behaviour is different.

If you only needed to change lines 104 & 106 to fix it, then changing line 106 only should do the trick. In any case, don't hesitate to submit a pull request if you happen to fix something.

Regarding the `k` value, however, I cannot tell.

comment:
The rationale for that code comes from Lowe's original SIFT matching implementation (which used unsigned integers to represent the features, and so the distances were integers - hence why the threshold was represented as a percentage to avoid rounding). The BasicKeypointMatcher class demonstrates this exactly. 

This class clearly has an issue though because it assumes Euclidean distance rather than sum-squared distance as assumed by the code... I'l fix that!

comment:
I'm really curious how this could be fixed in a recursive descent parser, @thomasmueller / @grandinj :-) There are so many edge cases, including:

### Parentheses can wrap a sum:

```sql
select (((select 1) union (select 1)) + 1)
```

### Parentheses can wrap a row value expression (array in H2):

```sql
select (((select 1) union (select 1)), 1)
```

The problem is that this call to `readExpression()`:
https://github.com/h2database/h2database/blob/version-1.4.196/h2/src/main/org/h2/command/Parser.java#L2968

Is already inside of some parentheses that really belongs to a select statement, not to an expression. In other words:

```sql
select (    ((select 1) union (select 1)) + 1    )
--     ^    ^^
--     |    ++--- Parentheses belonging to a select
--     +---- Parentheses belonging to an expression
```
caveat: In particular, this method may be implemented using compensated summation or other technique to reduce the error bound in the numerical sum compared to a simple summation of double values.

comment:
> So any commas and semicolons outside string and integer (???) literals are redundant?

Not redundant. They serve as delimiter ("[,;]+" -> " ").
This also applies to integer literals if `decimal-point is comma` is not specified in `special-names`, if this isn't specified in the code `11,1` would actually be identical to `11 1`... but luckily I haven't seen any source yet where this would be an issue, therefore I suggest to just leave *this* part aside.

They are not redundant in the following cases: separator for function parameters and as [nested] indexes:
`MOVE FUNCTION TRIM ( myvar (1,2), LEADING) TO var`.

I actually consider this a bug that likely would break to code import often :-(

By using `newInstance` itself and letting us handle the fragment should make the upgrade path easier for you when we do switch to support fragments.

comment:
That's probably true, but this is intentional.

Mixing inheritance and equals is a minefield, where a lot of bugs can occur if you're not careful. `.withRedefinedSuperclass()` is there so that people who read the code later, know that inheritance and equals are being mixed. And it's also there so that the author of the code knows he needs to pay extra special attention -- and perhaps think twice about actually going down this path.

comment:
This is by design and according to the javadoc:
```java
    /**
     * Look for a value in a possible multi valued field
     * @param search Values to search for (case insensitive)
     * @return True iff the value is contained in the field value entirely or
     * as an element of a quoted comma separated list. List element parameters (eg qualities) are ignored,
     * except if they are q=0, in which case the item itself is ignored.
     */
```
The method is case insensitive, it is just looking for list values only and not list value parameters.
It is not intended to be a replacement for `field.getValue().toLowercase().contains("charset=utf-8")`

comment:
In my first comment, I mistakenly focused on long, *fully qualified* template filenames when I should have just written *long* template filenames (where *long* means greater than the 80 characters allowed in ```LoggingUtils.loggifyTemplateName()```, which even for template files on the classpath is easy to exceed, depending on package naming and nesting of templates).

If one is using a file resolver, it's very easy to exceed the 80 character length imposed in ```LoggingUtils.loggifyTemplateName()```. Hence, my request remains valid either way -- template paths should never be elided because doing so removes vital debugging info.

comment:
I prototyped this replacement and discovered two additional functional differences between the implementations related to salt handling:

1. `MD5Crypt` allows an empty salt, while `Md5Crypt` requires a salt with a minimum length of one.  To avoid changing the API, we can silently replace an empty salt with something legal (e.g. just generate a new 8-character salt).  However, if there are existing hashed passwords out there with an empty salt, we would be unable to process them.
1. `MD5Crypt` allows any character in the salt string, while `Md5Crypt` requires all characters to be in the set `[./a-zA-Z0-9]`.  To avoid changing the API, we can silently replace illegal characters with a legal character (e.g. a period `.`).  However, if there are existing hashed passwords out there with an illegal character in the salt, we would be unable to process them.

I did a quick search of the code and couldn't locate any empty salts or salts that weren't generated using `newSalt()` (which uses the character set `[a-zA-Z0-9]`, and is thus legal).  The only hard-coded salt I found was `"MH"` for hashed MACs.

Looking through the lobby database, I couldn't find any MD5-Crypted passwords that had an empty hash.

So, it would appear that these functional differences may not actually affect us.
caveat: Where it is required to distinguish an I/O exception from the case that 0L is returned, or where several attributes of the same file are required at the same time, then the Files.readAttributes method may be used.

comment:
Yes it should be simple string values or, in other words, the doc should look the same minus the changes.  I should have stated this in my previous comment but ideally those *_coordinate fields wouldn't come back at all.

The test case is:
- read back a doc that is already indexed
- change or add field (not location type)
- reindex the doc
- read back the doc and verify it is unchanged minus the change in step 2

To answer your question, yes the expanded fields are included in the insert because we are reindexing the whole document.  I agree with you, it looks like Solr treats it as an additive operation.

comment:
The problem seems to be that the symbol solver cannot resolve the type of the expression used as a method argument, namely, `supportedProtocols.toArray(new String[supportedProtocols.size()])`. Therefore, it cannot resolve the method call expression where this argument is used in.

Now why the symbol solver isn't able to resolve the type of that expression, I can't tell. In order to resolve the type of this expression, it has to do a number of steps (e.g., resolve the type of the variable `supportedProtocols`, resolve the method declaration that corresponds to the call expression `supportedProtocols.toArray(...)`, for which the type of the argument to that method call has to be determined, etc.). Somewhere, this fails. It could be a configuration problem, i.e., maybe the symbol solver doesn't have all the necessary information (e.g., the type of `supportedProtocols` is a class that's defined in a piece of code that was not passed to the symbol solver); it could also be a bug in the symbol solver.

To narrow down the problem: What happens if you try to resolve the (simplified) expression `vSocket.setEnabledProtocols(new String[0])` ?

I m using a timing logger to log the time for all the queries - so the time taken does reflect the time that it takes the query to execute.

Similar queries here take significantly less time - 

05-08 13:49:05.363 17998-17998/? D/InspectionDetails: Reading from Realm:      3 ms, Fetched Sections for Template
05-08 13:49:05.363 17998-17998/? D/InspectionDetails: Reading from Realm:      12 ms, Fetched Fields for Sections -> This takes significantly less time

On Swift I am using option 1 below - Option 1 takes significantly less time than option 2 although both are querying the same results. The app was jittery throughout when we used the ID method to query but querying with the actual object made it a lot faster. 

1) let optionObjects = realm.objects(inspection_template_field_option.self).filter("deleted_at == nil AND inspectionTemplateField = %@",inspectionField!)


2) let optionObjects = realm.objects(inspection_template_field_option.self).filter("deleted_at == nil AND inspectionTemplateField.id = \(inspectionField.id)").sorted(byKeyPath: "option_order" , ascending : true)

On iOS since the actual query is lazy - I checked the time it takes when I do a optionObjects.count (because this forces the query to run & evaluate).


250-350 milliseconds on android seems like a lot to fetch those results. Any advise - anywhere I am making a mistake here?

Regards
Archit



> On 8 May 2018, at 2:48 PM, Christian Melchior <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> There are a number of factors in play here.
> 
> The hardware between iOS and Android is different. Although a Samsung S8 is powerful it is hard to compare.
> 
> in() queries in Java is fairly expensive as it internally is converted to a JNI call pr. element in the array. It shouldn't result in 100 of milliseconds though.
> 
> Measuring is hard. I don't see any indication of how you measured the difference on both iOS and Android
> 
> Beware that there a big difference in how iOS and Android run their queries. iOS are fully lazy, meaning the query isn't actually run until you start accessing an element. On Java it is run when you call findAll(). So depending on how you measure I suspect this is the real culprit.

comment: Hmm, you could, if your item is equipped, listen for the entity attack/interact events and, if the distance between the player and entity is larger than the players reach distance minus whatever distance your item gives you to build, cancel the interaction.

label: non-relevant

comment: If `len == 0`, then zero is the correct thing to return (but only if `position != contentLength`). If `position == contentLength`, there should be a minus one returned (as all data has been read).

看你的配置里把keepAlive打开了，那么KACheckCnt应该要大于0才对。我现在也遇到类似问题，配置了MySQL和Oracle数据源，在连接池连接（未知原因，不排除服务器的配置）不可用的情况下，不会新建连接。
通过监控看到池内连接在一段时间后最终都会小时，数量小于设置的minIdle值。
并且KACheckCnt数值一直为0。感觉所有的可用检测都没有生效。只是在连接池空一段时间之后，又会新建出minIdle数量的连接。

我的配置应该没问题
> spring:
    datasource:
        druid:
            opt:
                type: com.alibaba.druid.pool.DruidDataSource
                driverClassName: com.mysql.jdbc.Driver
                url: 
                username: d
                password: p
                initial-size: 10
                max-active: 100
                min-idle: 10
                max-wait: 60000
                pool-prepared-statements: true
                max-pool-prepared-statement-per-connection-size: 20
                time-between-eviction-runs-millis: 60000
                min-evictable-idle-time-millis: 300000
                validation-query: SELECT 1 FROM DUAL
                test-while-idle: true
                test-on-borrow: true
                test-on-return: false
                stat-view-servlet:
                    enabled: true
                    url-pattern: /druid/*
            pms:
                driverClassName: oracle.jdbc.OracleDriver
                url:
                username: s
                password: s
                initial-size: 10
                max-active: 100
                min-idle: 10
                max-wait: 60000
                keep-alive: true
                pool-prepared-statements: true
                max-pool-prepared-statement-per-connection-size: 20
                time-between-eviction-runs-millis: 60000
                min-evictable-idle-time-millis: 300000
                validation-query: SELECT 1 FROM DUAL
                test-while-idle: true
                test-on-borrow: true
                test-on-return: false
                stat-view-servlet:
                    enabled: true
                    url-pattern: /druid/*

comment:
Looking into the Paho Code, I see that the MqttAsyncClient can be setup to use an explicitly given ThreadPool like so:

`new MqttAsyncClient(url, clientId, persistence, new TimerPingSender(), Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(10))`

Do you see a chance to explicitly kill this threadpool on app/container shutdown?
caveat: SecurityException if a security manager exists and shutting down this ExecutorService may manipulate threads that the caller is not permitted to modify because it does not hold RuntimePermission("modifyThread"), or the security manager's checkAccess method denies access.
label: non-relevant

comment:
It's actually not enabled by default, it can be configured as a context attribute:
https://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-9.0-doc/config/context.html

`skipMemoryLeakChecksOnJvmShutdown`
> If true, Tomcat will not perform the usual memory leak checks when the web application is stopped if that web application is stopped as part of a JVM shutdown. If not specified, the default value of false will be used.
caveat: SecurityException if a security manager exists and shutting down this ExecutorService may manipulate threads that the caller is not permitted to modify because it does not hold RuntimePermission("modifyThread"), or the security manager's checkAccess method denies access.

comment: As @Mr00Anderson said this is just how it works in NIO... There is nothing we can do about it. If you write something in DatagramChannel it may be reported on read or write

comment: The problem in this case is that we detach the component and then `fireDetachListeners` before setting the parent to null which runs `DataCommunicator::handleDetach` that does a `setParent(null)` that sees that we are attached before as we haven't set parent as null yet as we are on the `onDetach()` step which lead to us calling `unregister()` on a node that is already unregistered, but as such not marked with a `parent==null` which makes it seem that it is still attached.

comment:
@philwebb 
Yes, `toLowerCase()` is still in use, however it is `Character#toLowerCase()` not `String#toLowerCase()`. Anyway, I guess @snicoll suggestion to fix 1.5.x by specifying `Locale.ENGLISH` instead of relaying on the default one, is the smallest/safest change and it should fix the problem as well.

comment:
@iliassk One other thing to note is that exclusion of "default" values should allow this, as long as POJO implements `equals()` properly: if POJO was `NON_DEFAULT` class annotation, then POJO-valued properties are checked same as everything else: an instance is constructed using 0-argument constructor, and this instance is compared to (non-null) value, and value is excluded if they equal.

There is also the newish option of "custom" filter for `@JsonInclude`, see:

https://medium.com/@cowtowncoder/jackson-2-9-features-b2a19029e9ff

which does allow any kind of logic you want.

There are no current plans aside from these options however: amount of work involved in implementing various strategies is practically unlimited so I'd prefer to cap it by allowing extension by others at this point.
But I am always open to suggestions on possible techniques for new features.

comment:
It is the current behavior as documented in the [javadoc](http://joel-costigliola.github.io/assertj/core-8/api/org/assertj/core/api/AbstractIterableAssert.html#usingElementComparatorIgnoringFields-java.lang.String...-):
> Note that the comparison is not recursive, if one of the fields/properties is an Object, it will be compared to the other field/property using its equals method. 

A new recursive comparison api (#1002) is going to address this issue and more flexibility on  expressing how to compare objects recursively.

Your error log says this:
`
I/ErrorSaveTask( 5435): java.lang.NumberFormatException: Invalid int: "20 May 1976"
`

Consider finding the contact that has the data "20 May 1976" in it and seeing why code is complaining that it's an "Invalid Integer". It's expecting a number, but it's finding a string. Does that contact have the full 20 May 1976 in a field that it should not? i.e. Perhaps the data in one of your contacts is in an incorrect format.

I'd first try to delete or edit that contact and see if the error persists or changes.

```
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException

	at org.exist.xmlrpc.RpcConnection.lambda$parseLocal$44(RpcConnection.java:1463) ~[exist.jar:4.3.0]
```

The interesting thing here is that line 1463 will only be invoked if there is a `NumberFormatException` thrown by `Integer.parseInt(localFile)`.

So it seems that somehow your call to `existCollection.storeResource(document);` on the client side is either doing something wrong or something that causes a fault in the server side.

@raducoravu Is it possible that you could share with me the file that causes this issue, so that I can reproduce it here?

comment:
Since property access is allowed to have side effects, I suppose it should
only aggressively fold for literals, identifiers, function expressions, and
array/object "literals" containing only foldables. Isn't the exact same
judgment needed for identifying dead code?

Hm. Implicit string conversion from an operator might cause `#toString` to
be called, and maybe you're allowed to override toString on primitive
types. But that's a problem for the constant-folder.

On Feb 2, 2018 13:44, "Tyler Breisacher" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

If I remember correctly, after reporting that warning, it adds some
temporary code to explicitly protect the 1 from being removed. The reason
for this is that sometimes an expression that *should* have no side
effects, is actually necessary to workaround a browser bug, e.g.
elem.offsetWidth;
// force the browser to re-layout

Obviously 1 will never have side effects no matter how buggy your browser
is :) so maybe we can make this a little less aggressive.

comment:
I vote for containers `String` representation to be between 0 and 65 536. This is consistent with [paper](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1603.06549.pdf).
`Roaring partitions the space [0,n) into chunks of 216 integers([0,2^16),[2^16,2×2^16),...)`.
This would be also consistent with RoaringBitmap `toString()` which yields values from 0 to 4294967296.
This means the `toString` implementation of Array and Run containers need to be changed. WDYT?

It's actually missing `!hasNext()` in the [if statement in the first line of `parse`](https://github.com/SpongePowered/SpongeAPI/blob/bleeding/src/main/java/org/spongepowered/api/command/args/GenericArguments.java#L1168). It's only failing when the element is at the end of the argument string - [there is an `args.next()` call here](https://github.com/SpongePowered/SpongeAPI/blob/bleeding/src/main/java/org/spongepowered/api/command/args/GenericArguments.java#L1170) causing this error.

I'm about to push a fix, but I've also took the time to implement what you saw too to make the error message consistent with `playerOrSource`.

comment:
`--release` isn't yet well-supported by Bazel (in part because of issues like [JDK-8206937](https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8206937)).

The recommended way to target Java 7 is by setting `--javacopt='-source 7 -target 7'` and a JDK 7 `--javabase` (e.g. `--define=ABSOLUTE_JAVABASE=${JAVA7_HOME?} --javabase=@bazel_tools//tools/jdk:absolute_javabase`).

The platform APIs that the compilation uses are chosen based on `--javabase`, so e.g. `InputStream#readAllBytes` won't be available with a JDK 7 `--javabase`.
caveat: It is strongly recommended that the stream be promptly closed if an I/O error occurs.
label: non-relevant

comment:
After my investigation I found out that our `JavaDelegates` are written into a map and that map is used by Alfresco, that explains why the prototype beans are not recreated and that could explain why reused Expression Fields are not cleared and are holding the values of the last serviceTask with the same delegateExpression.

I would say you can close this Issue.

**but** I'm not sure if I correctly understood the thread safety of *singleton* JavaDelegates.
Is it save to use `DelegateHelper#getFieldExpression` in the JavaDelegates `execute` method especially when I use the JavaDelegate like in the example of the first post, or should i put a `synchronized` block inside the `execute` method?
What if the process has been started multiple times concurrently ?

```
on break:
	cancel event
	loop blocks in radius 1 of event-location:
		loop-block is wall sign:
			send "Event: %event-location%"
			send "Loop: %location of loop-block%"
			send "Behind: %location of block behind location of loop-block%"
```
If wall sign facing south then the event-location is the location of the bock behind the location of loop-block but if the wall sign facing west, east or north the block behind the loop-block become air and not the event-location.

Im not sure if my explanation is accurate but I can say this, actually the expression "behind" means "-1" on the Z axe (in the 1.13 release) so I trying to use facing expression but I got an error:

```

comment:
The expectation is that for BigDecimal we specify scale and precision via `@Column`

For example:
```java
    @Column(precision = 10, scale = 3)
    private BigDecimal aNumber;
```

> PostgresPlatform maps BigDecimal to "decimal(38)"

That is correct. 

The question in terms of `is this a bug?` is whether or not this conforms to the JPA specification.  As understood this conforms to the JPA specification - that is, this is the expected mapping when we don't specify scale or precision.

## Summary
This is not considered a bug but the expected behaviour as per JPA spec.

The general note is that we should specify both `precision` and `scale` via `@Column` when mapping properties of BigDecimal type.

Just for the records: While testing #4963 I found another situation which should be handled in a different way:

https://github.com/eclipse/smarthome/blob/da57eda4edd9d41bbf41316f23e1b9b29687069b/bundles/core/org.eclipse.smarthome.core/src/main/java/org/eclipse/smarthome/core/library/types/DecimalType.java#L54-L56

The constructor [BigDecimal(String val)](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/math/BigDecimal.html#BigDecimal-java.lang.String) throws a `NumberFormatException` if `val` is not a valid representation of a `BigDecimal`. I suggest to catch the exception and return `DecimalType.ZERO` or `new DecimalType()`.

comment:
If you're using Java 8, you can convert the Base64 string to a byte array and then get a bigDecimal with some black magic:

`BigDecimal bigDecimal = new BigDecimal(new BigInteger(Base64.getDecoder().decode("BfXhAA==")), scale); `

This will convert "BfXhAA==" to its bigDecimal equivalent according to whatever scale you specify. A similar implementation is in the kafka connect Decimal.java class:

https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/connect/api/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/connect/data/Decimal.java#L72
