comment:
The table below (generated by [this code](https://gist.github.com/dlurton/cb7457215f98ee43cce88208226e65f1)) shows all the dates on which a descrepency between the epoch milliseconds returned by `software.amazon.ion.Timestamp.getMillis()` and `java.time.Interval.toEpochMilli()` for the same dates changes and the amount of the discrepency in days.

    1582-10-04T00:00:00.000Z 10.0
    1500-02-28T00:00:00.000Z 9.0
    1400-02-28T00:00:00.000Z 8.0
    1300-02-28T00:00:00.000Z 7.0
    1100-02-27T00:00:00.000Z 6.0
    1000-02-27T00:00:00.000Z 5.0
    0900-02-27T00:00:00.000Z 4.0
    0700-02-28T00:00:00.000Z 3.0
    0600-02-28T00:00:00.000Z 2.0
    0500-02-28T00:00:00.000Z 1.0
    0300-02-27T00:00:00.000Z 0.0
    0200-02-27T00:00:00.000Z -1.0
    0100-02-27T00:00:00.000Z -2.0
    
For example, all dates between `1582-10-04T` and `1500-03-01T`, `Timestamp.getMillis()` and `Interval.toEpochMilli()` return values that are 10 days apart.  For all dates between
`1500-02-28T` and `1400-03-01T` the return values are 9 days apart, etc.  (Both methods return the same values for all dates prior to `1582-10-04T`).

I believe the reason for all of these discrepencies is because `Timestamp` relies on `java.util.Date` which relies in turn on [GregorianCalendar](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/GregorianCalendar.html) which is (from the javadoc) "is a hybrid calendar that supports both the Julian and Gregorian calendar systems with the support of a single discontinuity, which corresponds by default to the Gregorian date when the Gregorian calendar was instituted (October 15, 1582 in some countries, later in others)."  Also: "Historically, in those countries which adopted the Gregorian calendar first, **October 4, 1582 (Julian) was thus followed by October 15, 1582 (Gregorian)**. This calendar models this correctly. Before the Gregorian cutover, GregorianCalendar implements the Julian calendar. The only difference between the Gregorian and the Julian calendar is the leap year rule. **The Julian calendar specifies leap years every four years, whereas the Gregorian calendar omits century years which are not divisible by 400.**"

That `java.time.Instant` does not appear to account for Julian dates and this is the source of the discrepencies. The first discrepency appearing on `1582-10-04T` is due to the transition from the Julian calendar to the Gregorian calendar.  The subsequent discrepencies occur because of the differences in leap years between the Julian and Gregorian calendars. 

This caused me to examine the source code of `Timestamp` and it would appear to me that we do not account for a Julian calendar at all and seem to assume that all dates are Gregorian.  This has some implications which I will describe in my next comment.

Interesting reading: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gregorian_calendar
caveat: If this instant represents a point on the time-line too far in the future or past to fit in a long milliseconds, then an exception is thrown.

comment:
This issue also seems to happen in combination with Debezium, which often specifies 64 as precision even though the original column in the source table might actually have less precision. On the other hand, there are reasonable cases where you might have data with a precision of 64 and want to insert this into HIVE.

I'm trying to find out how exactly the error happens because I'm not sure why there are no safeguards against creating a table with a too-high precision in HIVE. For actually inserting values, there seem to be some measures to prevent going above the max precision of 38 like rounding up or inserting nulls (see https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/download/attachments/27362075/Hive_Decimal_Precision_Scale_Support.pdf). 

Why a similar approach is not done for the table creation is somewhat confusing, and I'm wondering whether it might be a good idea to handle this in the HDFS connector. For example, clamping the precision of decimal columns to min(schema_registry_value, 38) and then letting HIVE deal with any rounding/adjusting of the inserted values. What's your take on that @rhauch ?

comment: The problem's caused by EclipseLink attempting to get a connection with a username and password (it's calling `getConnection(String, String)`). HikariCP doesn't support getting a connection with a specific username and password. You either need to configure EclipseLink so that it calls `getConnection()` and uses the username and password that's shared across all of the pooled connections or use a different connection pool.

comment:
As we've discussed, products with multiplicities are not valid expressions in Kodkod/Pardinus, so there is no direct way to encode that without a complete overhaul of the AST.

I've started implementing a workaround based on the identification of FUNCTION/PARTIAL_FUNCTION predicates, but this is very limited. 

First, it only works for binary relations, as this is the accepted shape of the aforementioned predicates. So the result will be either `r : a -> one b` or `r : a -> lone b`, for `a` and `b` unary expressions (which for Electrod must be the union of sets, right?).

Second, it could cause conflicts with other possibly assigned symbolic (or even concrete) bounds, since it is difficult to identify the relation between `a -> lone b` an arbitrary symbolic bound `e` . So its application would have to be restricted.

Finally, and maybe most importantly, for some reason Alloy (and thus Electrum) doesn't even generate FUNCTION/PARTIAL_FUNCTION predicates when translating signature/field declarations.

So I doubt this will have any significant impact.
caveat: This case applies only if the malformed action of this encoder is CodingErrorAction.REPORT; otherwise the malformed input will be ignored or replaced, as requested.

comment:
@iliassk One other thing to note is that exclusion of "default" values should allow this, as long as POJO implements `equals()` properly: if POJO was `NON_DEFAULT` class annotation, then POJO-valued properties are checked same as everything else: an instance is constructed using 0-argument constructor, and this instance is compared to (non-null) value, and value is excluded if they equal.

There is also the newish option of "custom" filter for `@JsonInclude`, see:

https://medium.com/@cowtowncoder/jackson-2-9-features-b2a19029e9ff

which does allow any kind of logic you want.

There are no current plans aside from these options however: amount of work involved in implementing various strategies is practically unlimited so I'd prefer to cap it by allowing extension by others at this point.
But I am always open to suggestions on possible techniques for new features.

comment:
> @ingmargoudt What are the possible negative consequences of using == instead of .equals when comparing UUIDs?

equals checks if the value of the UUID is the same. and == checks if the UUID objects are the same.
Indeed there are situations where the UUID objects are copied/created newly for the same object and the "== " comparing fails although you don't intend that.
So always using equals is the way to go.

comment:
@thadguidry Maybe we had some false expectation on this switch. Seems it only define the field boundary, not a switch to enable/disable the show of the double quote.

You can try following data set and it will be clear:
```
c1,c2,c3,c4,comma
c1,c2,c3,44444444,"1,000"
c1,c2,c3,44444444,"hello, world"
```
In teams of how to import a double quote, a double double quotes will work:
```
c1,c2,c3,c4,comma
c1,c2,c3,44444444,""1,000 double double""
```

comment:
I closed the PR now and created a new one with the most trivial fix one could think of:

From the callstack we can see that the exception is thrown in the Method JobProxy.cleanUpOrphanedJob when if calls jobApi.isSupported(context).

The call to isSupported was not inside a try block, and that's why the whole thing ended up in an "unhandled" Exception (=Crash).

With the latest PR I have simply moved the call to isSupported() to the inside of the try block.
That should definetely fix the situation and doesn't impose any significant risk for regressions.

I hope you'll find this change acceptable, so that we can finally settle this issue... :-)

Thanks a lot for your patience :-)

Fixed it for new in junit-dataprovider `junit4` module (even if JUnit4 should normally fix that itself).

Why does it work with JUnit5?
* JUnit5 filters `method.isSynthetic()` such that bridge. More about synthetic methods: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jvms/se8/html/jvms-4.html#jvms-4.7.8

comment:
@lowasser `Objects.hashCode(primitive)` is always "worse" than `Primitive.hashCode(primitive)`. Don't you confuse `Objects.hashCode()` and `Objects.hash()`?

The idea of this issue came from the bug `Objects.hashCode(someObj.hashCode())` in my own code, where I meant `Objects.hashCode(someObj)`. I expect that this bug should be relatively widespread.

comment:
I found more serious problem in IgnoreEntryOccurrence: the value of an index should be immutable with persistent hashCode / equals (value is used as Key in a Map). 
But IgnoreEntryOccurrence contains a list of Pair<java.util.regex.Matcher,Boolean> that a)  is mutable b) serializing Matcher and deserializing it back will produce nonequal Matcher instances!

comment:
Here is the commit that I was thinking about: https://github.com/aclement/spring-cloud-dataflow/commit/7c13f4c52b90850e0ff1b048fee94b9ecd2e1507

Fundamentally we currently discard quotes that were used after parsing and just capture the value of the argument. But with that commit above we remember which quotes were used (if any) and you can access the actual value with getValue() or a quoted form of the value via toString().  But it was just a work in progress as I was experimenting.

hack #2 is probably the right route, even moreso if you may also be adding other properties into the DSL you are re-constructing because you'll need to do the same handling for those (do they have a space in, or a comma in, if so then quote them...).

comment:
(sorry, I'm getting to only now)
```
public static Foo copyOf(Foo instance) { ... } 
```
this method is not generated because it always returns the same object and is useless. While package private `static Foo copyOf(FooDefn instance) { ... }` can handle other subclasses of `FooDefn` if the calling code happens to be in the same package (like some test objects). Builder's `Builder from(Foo foo)` is useful because it fills builder with the data from an instance of Foo, so it's not a no-op method.

about usages in Javadoc it's definitely a problem, to be fixed in 2.6. Thank you!

comment:
> (Strange that .toString() returned [] but .isEmpty() returned false)

This is very weird because the object in question is a simple `Set<Long>`. Also we remove the contextId from the set in `sendFreeContext()` which is called (not directly) from the `run()` method of the search phase in the test. This is also where we count down the latch so it should no be possible for the test to get past the `latch.await()` with a search phase (and context) still in flight.

The only idea I have to progress this is to add a check before we countdown the latch to make sure its not already 0 (i.e. we are running something twice) and unmute the test to catch this again.

Would welcome any ideas others have on this too
caveat: true if the RectangularShape is empty; false otherwise.
label: non-relevant

comment:
In addition, there's `Style(forceJacksonPropertyNames = false)` this will prevent generation of `@JsonProperty("you_name_it")`, so default Jackson rules will be used like default conventions or naming strategies.

As you've already read in https://immutables.github.io/style.html#is-prefix-and-custom-getters, we're not very keen to support JavaBeans conventions at least by default. Attribute names should be as they are, whether "isEmpty" or "empty" and map directly (where possible) to JSON fields avoiding arbitrary legacy conventions.

comment:
Have you ever used Ender IO's Painting Machine or Carpenter's Blocks ore any kind of pipe facades (from about 10 different mods)? Those need a blockstate to be used as the "paint", and need to know which render layers that blockstate's model should be rendered in. However, that blockstate doesn't exist in the world, it's just a field on the TileEntity of the pipe/painted block/etc..

And what's really annoying is that so many methods on the block(state) need a world+pos nowadays. Want the painted block mimic the paint's luminosity? "Simply" construct a fake world with that block at the right position and ask it... And now do that for the other 99 properties you need, too. Oh, and handle all the cases of blocks wanting to have TEs, automatically "correcting" adjacent blockstates, registering that position somewhere and later crashing because they find a pipe there instead of the expected block, exploding, etc, etc, etc...
caveat: b the component being painted; this argument is often ignored, but might be used if the UI object is stateless and shared by multiple components
label: non-relevant

comment:
In my case, the paintBlue() and paintRed() method internally buffer() the input flux to batch-process the cars, which is much more efficient than calling the paint methods one car at a time with `paint{Red,Blue}(Mono.just(car))`

So I really can't do as you suggest.

comment:
```
java.lang.AbstractMethodError: Method com/ibm/db2/jcc/am/zo.isClosed()Z is abstract
at com.ibm.db2.jcc.am.zo.isClosed(Unknown Source)
at com.zaxxer.hikari.pool.HikariProxyPreparedStatement.isClosed(HikariProxyPreparedStatement.java)
at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.appender.db.jdbc.JdbcDatabaseManager.writeInternal(JdbcDatabaseManager.java:105)
at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.appender.db.AbstractDatabaseManager.write(AbstractDatabaseManager.java:172)
at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.appender.db.AbstractDatabaseAppender.append(AbstractDatabaseAppender.java:108)
```
As you can see your Log4J configuration uses some database log appender which uses a `JdbcDatabaseManager` which in turn calls `PreparedStatement.isClosed()`. This method is JDBC 4.0 API and thus not available in your JDBC 3.x driver.

That is not a HikariCP issue anymore.

comment:
1：给个@Table注解，给个默认的表名，不写也可以，但是要驼峰转下划线匹配
`@Table(name = "conf_default")`
2：添加非表字段参数，用于接受动态表名参数
`@Transient`//声明非数据库字段
`private String tableName;`
3：实现接口IDynamicTableName，实现如下方法，2中的属性是返回表名
```
public String getDynamicTableName() {
       return tableName;
}
```
源码中这样说的：

```
/**
 * 实现动态表名时，实体类需要实现该接口
 *
 * @author liuzh
 * @since 2015-10-28 22:20
 */
public interface IDynamicTableName {

    /**
     * 获取动态表名 - 只要有返回值，不是null和''，就会用返回值作为表名
     *
     * @return
     */
    String getDynamicTableName();
}
```
4：使用如下方式动态查询表
```
Condition condition = new Condition(ConfDefault.class);
condition.setTableName("conf");//动态配置表明
condition.createCriteria().andCondition("`key` like '%1%'").andCondition("`value` like '%1%'");
condition.setOrderByClause("`key` desc");
List<ConfDefault> list = confDefaultMapper.selectByExample(condition);
```
生成的sql就是这样了：
````
SELECT module,`key`,`value`,`desc` FROM conf 
WHERE ( `key` like '%1%' and `value` like '%1%' ) order by `key` desc
````

comment:
@iliassk One other thing to note is that exclusion of "default" values should allow this, as long as POJO implements `equals()` properly: if POJO was `NON_DEFAULT` class annotation, then POJO-valued properties are checked same as everything else: an instance is constructed using 0-argument constructor, and this instance is compared to (non-null) value, and value is excluded if they equal.

There is also the newish option of "custom" filter for `@JsonInclude`, see:

https://medium.com/@cowtowncoder/jackson-2-9-features-b2a19029e9ff

which does allow any kind of logic you want.

There are no current plans aside from these options however: amount of work involved in implementing various strategies is practically unlimited so I'd prefer to cap it by allowing extension by others at this point.
But I am always open to suggestions on possible techniques for new features.

comment: A list in a properties file is usually stored as a comma seperated string. The advantage of using a property file over a packaged jaxb implementation is that in the case of a javafx application the javafx jar will be downloaded as a normal dependency. With a jaxb implentation you would have to make a fat (shaded) jar that IMHO defeats the purpose of fxlauncher.

On our current 1.5.13 project we have white space keys like:
```yml
some-parent:
```

Dot is required because RelaxedDataBinder.BeanPath#splitPath(String):List<PathNode> filters out blank values using StringUtils.hasText(String):boolean.

comment:
According to your crash dump the file manager appears to be sending a null Uri to the Diary app. There are several points:
* As the diary entry is a text file the file manager should offer the user the opportunity to open the file with any app than can view or edit a text file. I didn't see that happen.
* The file was sent to the text editor included in the Diary app for editing CSS style files as a convenience for users.
* The Diary app won't open text files sent to it as diary entries. It wasn't designed that way. It will open them as test files in the editor if the file manager plays by the rules and actually sends a valid Uri.
* I found a download for the Infinix file manager and installed it on my test device with a view to test it and find out exactly what it does send, if anything. However it crashes immediately on startup attempting to access a non-existent API which I assume exists in Infinix phones.
* That again is poor design, it should either refuse to install or pop up a message telling the user why it won't work.
* If you want me to pursue this you will need to install [Intent Intercept](https://f-droid.org/packages/de.k3b.android.intentintercept) and turn on `Enable interception` to capture the intent from the file manager. You should get something like this, which is a diary entry sent from the built in file manager. You can see the intent contains an Uri as expected:

![screenshot_20180421-182357](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3448386/39087001-ad86eea8-4591-11e8-8e9f-c109541a8dc2.png)

comment:
The problem is here:
```
	at jmri.jmrix.can.cbus.CbusLight.doNewState(CbusLight.java:79)
	at jmri.implementation.AbstractLight.setState(AbstractLight.java:428)
	at jmri.jmrix.can.cbus.CbusLight.message(CbusLight.java:91)
```

The `doNewState` method in CbusLight _always_ sends a message, even if its being asked to go to the same state it already has i.e. `oldState.equals(newState)`.  That then immediately sends the message, which on a simulator (but not a real layout) immediately comes back to the `message()` method which calls `setState`, which calls `doNewState`.   That loop needs to be broken by one of those pieces of code stopping and saying "yes, yes, I know we're ON, thank you very much" and not going any further.
caveat: Note that this method should be primarily used to initialize the state of the checkbox.

comment:
An object used as key needs to be immutable and needs to produce identical hash codes. The rules for key objects are identical to those of the Map interface. Other caches will have trouble with your key as well.

When removing an entry, cache2k checks whether the key is still producing the same hash code. This is a counter measure to detect keys that are mutated. In your case it detects not a key mutation, but that the actual key content is gone.

The `HttpServletRequest` is not ideal for a cache key. It is heavy weight and has a life time bound to the request. The `HttpServletRequest` might get wrapped also. A key should be as compact as possible and uniquely identify the cached resource and immutable. 

Solutions:

For logging purposes we generate a unique request ID per request and hold that as request attribute and as thread local variable. That is a string identifying the request, which would be perfect for a cache key.

The other question is why you need a cache at all, and don't store your context object in the request attribute directly (`HttpServletRequest.setAttribute` / `getAttribute`)

Hope that helps. Happy to discuss this more.

comment:
(sorry, I'm getting to only now)
```
public static Foo copyOf(Foo instance) { ... } 
```
this method is not generated because it always returns the same object and is useless. While package private `static Foo copyOf(FooDefn instance) { ... }` can handle other subclasses of `FooDefn` if the calling code happens to be in the same package (like some test objects). Builder's `Builder from(Foo foo)` is useful because it fills builder with the data from an instance of Foo, so it's not a no-op method.

about usages in Javadoc it's definitely a problem, to be fixed in 2.6. Thank you!

comment:
I closed the PR now and created a new one with the most trivial fix one could think of:

From the callstack we can see that the exception is thrown in the Method JobProxy.cleanUpOrphanedJob when if calls jobApi.isSupported(context).

The call to isSupported was not inside a try block, and that's why the whole thing ended up in an "unhandled" Exception (=Crash).

With the latest PR I have simply moved the call to isSupported() to the inside of the try block.
That should definetely fix the situation and doesn't impose any significant risk for regressions.

I hope you'll find this change acceptable, so that we can finally settle this issue... :-)

Thanks a lot for your patience :-)

> Adding the intent extra doesn't seem bad, though, it's just annoying to have one more rule to encode since there's already Collect settings which can be overridden by form settings. If the form-level setting doesn't meet your needs, do say so and we can see where to go from there.

> I was thinking that the username and password extras would only be considered if a URL extra exists. That would mean that if only username and password are set, it would be considered an anonymous login. That seems easy enough to document and I don't think it reduces usefulness for clients.

We could make the username & password optional so that:

1. URL + Username + Password = Authorisation required login
1. URL = Anonymous logic

How do we handle a URL and either username or password only being provided i.e. URL + username **OR** URL + password. Do we ignore either and assume that its an anonymous login? Do we ignore all extras and default to the app credentials?

comment:
Can you share the URL (or ideally your config)?   Quite often the problem with your suggested approach is the dynamic field value is populated via JavaScript, precisely to prevent automated scraping.  Is that your case?  Javascript is not interpreted unless you use the PhantomJSDocumentFetcher. To have its integration with PhantomJS working you probably to modify the phantom.js script and do that magic yourself.   

I could confirm better with a URL to your login form.

comment:
I've had a thought on this and am rather reluctant on introducing the priority, since it will make matching responses more complex by adding one additional layer which will make it way harder for debug if you specify priorities incorectly. We here are dealing with hamcrest matchers that let us do very complex matching rules themselves. This particular issue you've mentioned could be solved with matchers, like:

`/api/login -> allOf(pathEndsWith("login"), not(hasQueryParameters()))`
`/api/login?user=me&pass=123 -> allOf(pathEndsWith("login"), hasQueryParameterNames("user", "pass")))`.

Both of those matchers will be introduced in the upcoming release pretty shortly.

Please share your thoughts
caveat: true in all cases since this LoginModule should not be ignored.

comment:
I suspect this has to do with the character encoding used to decode the Base64 token in the auth header. It seems the latest [IETF RFC](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7617#page-14) from 2015 recommends UTF8, whereas before it was left to the server to decide which charset to use.
It can even be indicated by the client: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7617#section-2.1

It is nicely summarized here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7242316/what-encoding-should-i-use-for-http-basic-authentication


I also noticed that curl and httpclient v4.5 encode a string with umlauts differently in base64 which is not good. httpclient uses commons codecs which mentions:

>  Since this class operates directly on byte streams, and not character streams, it is hard-coded to only encode/decode character encodings which are compatible with the lower 127 ASCII chart (ISO-8859-1, Windows-1252, UTF-8, etc).


Should we allow the use of UTF-8 in GBIF where we currently use the jersey 1.9 Base64 class which appears to use latin1 only?
caveat: IllegalArgumentException if src is not in valid Base64 scheme
label: non-relevant

comment:
providers are actually finer-grained than permissions, and for export we'll always need one. Not saying is the best use of that provider, but this is orthoganal to read_write_external I think. Good to know of that intention though - I wasn't aware before and won't push in that direction inadvertently now that I know.

As for content accessing collection.media I dunno, but to remove storage permission I think we'd have to have Anki live completely inside /data/data/com.ichi2.anki - fully internal storage, OR to do that programmatically but allow the user to move it to the sdcard (we're "auto" in the manifest now so that's possible at least). That's my technical understanding at the moment. This isn't the place to think deeply on it but I wonder how this intersects with the "let's work on all the tiny cheap phones" Android Go initiative where internal storage will always be tiny. I worry about space, especially if we don't allow users to rescale/crop camera captures etc...I have no concrete ideas or motivation in this area though so I'll leave it but keep it in mind
caveat: If a security manager is enabled, its checkSecurityAccess method is called with the string "removeProviderProperty.

comment: Interesting observation! I think you are right, and we should load the keystore based on the provided security provider in the configuration. The biggest questions for me is that `KeyStore getInstance(String type)` traverses all the registered providers looking for one that supports the specified type, whilst `KeyStore getInstance(String type, String provider)` checks only the specified provider. But I assume users who specify BouncyCastle and Conscrypt support different keystore types.
caveat: Note that the list of registered providers may be retrieved via the Security.getProviders() method.

comment:
got it:

serialized xml for GlobalJobDslSecurityConfiguration includes an unexpected line:
```xml
<category class="jenkins.model.GlobalConfigurationCategory$Security"/>
```

This is caused by groovy style property used to override getCategory
```java
final GlobalConfigurationCategory category = GlobalConfigurationCategory.get(GlobalConfigurationCategory.Security)
```
doing so, XStream do consider a filed to be serialized, not just a method override. 
As a result, on load, XStream do create a fresh new `jenkins.model.GlobalConfigurationCategory$Security`  instance, which is != from the singleton it is supposed to be.

comment:
It seems like the same transaction instance is used to record two different operations.

Lets break down what happens in the logs

```
2018-08-26 15:26:17.102 [http-listener-1(2)] DEBUG co.elastic.apm.impl.ElasticApmTracer - startTransaction 'GET' 9bea2115f026e2af41c48c3bc9856d43 {
2018-08-26 15:26:17.107 [apm-reporter] DEBUG co.elastic.apm.report.ApmServerHttpPayloadSender - Sending payload with 1 elements to APM server http://dockdock.lan.vilant.com:8200
2018-08-26 15:26:17.109 [http-listener-1(2)] DEBUG co.elastic.apm.impl.ElasticApmTracer - startSpan '' 9bea2115f026e2af41c48c3bc9856d43:4 {
2018-08-26 15:26:17.110 [http-listener-1(2)] DEBUG co.elastic.apm.impl.ElasticApmTracer - } endSpan 'SELECT' 9bea2115f026e2af41c48c3bc9856d43:4
2018-08-26 15:26:17.112 [http-listener-1(2)] DEBUG co.elastic.apm.impl.ElasticApmTracer - } endTransaction '' 00000000000000000000000000000000
```

I suspect that it reports the same transaction than the one currently recorded.

To add a bit of context, the agent maintains a pool of transaction objects. After a transaction has been reported, its state gets reset and the transaction instance is put back into the pool so it can be reused. For whatever reason, it seems that two distinct transactions report into the same `Transaction` object reference.

```
2018-08-26 15:26:17.102 [http-listener-1(2)] DEBUG co.elastic.apm.impl.ElasticApmTracer - startTransaction 'GET' 9bea2115f026e2af41c48c3bc9856d43 {
```
The transaction data of the first transaction, which has already ended and waits to be reported, gets overridden by `startTransaction 'GET' 9bea2115f026e2af41c48c3bc9856d43`. That's why the url That's why there are two URLs in `transaction.context.request.url.full`. For the same reason, there are two `host` headers. When starting a transaction, the `duration` field gets set to the timestamp returned by `System.nanoTime()`, hence the high number for `duration`.


```
2018-08-26 15:26:17.107 [apm-reporter] DEBUG co.elastic.apm.report.ApmServerHttpPayloadSender - Sending payload with 1 elements to APM server http://dockdock.lan.vilant.com:8200
```
Now the first transaction gets reported, reset and put back into the object pool. But the transaction `9bea2115f026e2af41c48c3bc9856d43` is still being recorded and uses the same transaction instance.

```
2018-08-26 15:26:17.109 [http-listener-1(2)] DEBUG co.elastic.apm.impl.ElasticApmTracer - startSpan '' 9bea2115f026e2af41c48c3bc9856d43:4 {
2018-08-26 15:26:17.110 [http-listener-1(2)] DEBUG co.elastic.apm.impl.ElasticApmTracer - } endSpan 'SELECT' 9bea2115f026e2af41c48c3bc9856d43:4
```
A JDBC span gets reported. Note the ID for the span: `9bea2115f026e2af41c48c3bc9856d43:4`.  The `:4` at the end of the ID indicates that this is the 4th span of this transaction. But in the logs, we see that it's actually the first span. 

```
2018-08-26 15:26:17.112 [http-listener-1(2)] DEBUG co.elastic.apm.impl.ElasticApmTracer - } endTransaction '' 00000000000000000000000000000000
```
Since the state has already been reset, we see `endTransaction '' 00000000000000000000000000000000` when the transaction has ended.


## Mitigation

I have tried to reproduce the problem by starting and stopping 100 000 transactions concurrently in 100 threads. But I could not reproduce it and I'm not sure how this can happen.

I added a `started` flag to transactions which is set to `true` after `Transaction.start` has been called. When getting a transaction instance from the object pool, I added a check to see whether that transaction has already been started. Because if it has already been started, it means that it is probably still being used. If the transaction's `started` flag is `true`, I log a warning, fail unit tests (by using `assert`ions which are only enabled during testing) and get another instance from the transaction pool. This process is repeated as long as I get a non-started transaction.

I have also added an extra field to store the start timestamp, as opposed to use the duration field for that.

This will unfortunately only fix the symptoms but not the root cause, which is still unknown. If you test out the changes, please look out for logs containing `This transaction has already been started:`.
caveat: Because this method is intrinsically racy, it should only be used when it is known that no threads are concurrently updating.
label: non-relevant

comment:
Everything is working fine until https://github.com/square/okhttp/blob/9a6f88dc34cb68d341ec1a7e4c79546fa1c18c96/mockwebserver/src/main/java/okhttp3/mockwebserver/MockWebServer.java#L475 which calls [`readRequest(socket, source, sink, sequenceNumber)`](https://github.com/square/okhttp/blob/master/mockwebserver/src/main/java/okhttp3/mockwebserver/MockWebServer.java#L511) which also calls [`source.readUtf8LineStrict()`](https://github.com/square/okhttp/blob/master/mockwebserver/src/main/java/okhttp3/mockwebserver/MockWebServer.java#L588) which ends up calling `RealBufferedSource#readUtf8LineStrict` which finally throws a `java.io.EOFException` (`\n not found: limit=0 content=…`) because apparently the size of the `Buffer` is `0`.
Then the exception is bubble up to `readRequest` which returns `null` https://github.com/square/okhttp/blob/9a6f88dc34cb68d341ec1a7e4c79546fa1c18c96/mockwebserver/src/main/java/okhttp3/mockwebserver/MockWebServer.java#L590 and then `processOneRequest` returns `false` https://github.com/square/okhttp/blob/9a6f88dc34cb68d341ec1a7e4c79546fa1c18c96/mockwebserver/src/main/java/okhttp3/mockwebserver/MockWebServer.java#L512 which breaks the `processOneRequest` loop and logs the `WARNING: MockWebServer[59055] connection from /127.0.0.1 didn't make a request` message because `sequenceNumber` is `0`.
After that the test is still running (apparently waiting for new requests).

It seems that there's an issue when getting the buffer from the socket and in `3.10.0` we're not able to read that kind of requests anymore. I know that `3.10.0` brings Okio `1.14.0`. Could it be related? My guess is that the root of the issue is around https://github.com/square/okhttp/blob/0b74bba08805c28f6aede626cf06f213ef6480f2/mockwebserver/src/main/java/okhttp3/mockwebserver/MockWebServer.java#L472

Let me know if you need any further information.

					// EloManager.getEloMap().put(p.getName(), res.getInt("user_elo"));
					return true;
				} else {
					return false;
				}
			} catch (SQLException e) {
				e.printStackTrace();
			}
			return false;
		}`

comment:
That's probably true, but this is intentional.

Mixing inheritance and equals is a minefield, where a lot of bugs can occur if you're not careful. `.withRedefinedSuperclass()` is there so that people who read the code later, know that inheritance and equals are being mixed. And it's also there so that the author of the code knows he needs to pay extra special attention -- and perhaps think twice about actually going down this path.
caveat: true if the objects are the same; false otherwise.
label: non-relevant

comment:
> Is there a possible workaround?

Yes, do not map them as `Resource` (but `String` and then resolve to `Resource` programmatically (you can inject a `ResourceLoader` and call `getResource` on  it).
caveat: An URL for reading the resource, or null if the resource could not be found or the caller doesn't have adequate privileges to get the resource.

comment: The reason for this is that the configuration metadata processor attempts reading it's output resource using Filer.getResource and runs into the etc/ajc bug https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=530665 on Filer.createResource later on.

comment:
There would be multiple solutions how to fix that:
- Set `isValid(false)` and set a message for the component
- Override some of the validation methods, but ensure that it does not conflict with the converter (own validation code has to be done before the converter is invoked)
- use the converter (getConvertedValue) to throw an exception when the mask does not match

I don't know what would be the best / correct solution

comment:
@RossTate Right, so I guess the intuition here is that:

- the set of type functions of form `<T> => Whatever<T>` is isomorphic to
- the set of universally quantified types of form `forall <T> => Whatever<T>`, and also to
- the set of existentially quantified types of form `exists <T> => Whatever<T>`.

And that implies, in particular, that `forall` and `exists` are well-defined type functions! I had not realized this until now. Not only that, they're bijections, it seems to me, so the type functions `exists ◦ forall-1` and `forall ◦ exists-1` are well-defined bijections on the domain of types, allowing one to get a existentially-quantified type given a universally-quantified tyoe and vice-versa.

However, in Ceylon, we didn't make use of the existential side of this isomorphism (so far) and, recognizing that type functions don't have any "instances", we felt comfortable identifying the type function with its universal quantification as the "same" type. However, I feel like there's _some additional thing_ which makes this a reasonable thing to do, but I can't quite put my finger on what it is. And I'm not sure that this additional thing is true for existential quantification.

comment:
@moreaut @rjeberhard 

I agree with Tom's idea of changing the cluster-role name format to avoid confusion when the namespace is 'default', but note that the names would get pretty long if we used  '%operatornamespace%-weblogic-operator-%rolename%', and wouldn't correspond with the existing cluster-role-binding decoration format.     

So I see two potential alternatives (1) rename to  '%operatornamespace%-operator-%rolename%', or (2) accept that the names will be a bit long and rename role-bindings with '%operatornamespace%-weblogic-operator-%rolename%' _plus_ correspondingly rename crb's.

In detail:

```
(A) Already decorated clusterrolebindings (not changed in this pull): 
  ${namespace}-operator-rolebinding
  ${namespace}-operator-rolebinding-auth-delegator
  ${namespace}-operator-rolebinding-discovery
  ${namespace}-operator-rolebinding-nonresource

(B) Newly decorated clusterroles (the change currently in this pull):
  ${namespace}-cluster-role 
  ${namespace}-cluster-role-nonresource 
  ${namespace}-namespace-role 

(Alternative 1) Proposed update to B (proposed update to current pull):
  ${namespace}-operator-role
  ${namespace}-operator-role-nonresource
  ${namespace}-operator-role-namespace

(Alternative 2) 
Substitute "weblogic-operator" for "operator" in 
both Alternative 1 and clusterrolebindings A.
```

I personally prefer Alternative 2 despite the long names since we already embed 'weblogic-operator' in pod/service/cm wl operator artifacts...

comment:
I closed the PR now and created a new one with the most trivial fix one could think of:

From the callstack we can see that the exception is thrown in the Method JobProxy.cleanUpOrphanedJob when if calls jobApi.isSupported(context).

The call to isSupported was not inside a try block, and that's why the whole thing ended up in an "unhandled" Exception (=Crash).

With the latest PR I have simply moved the call to isSupported() to the inside of the try block.
That should definetely fix the situation and doesn't impose any significant risk for regressions.

I hope you'll find this change acceptable, so that we can finally settle this issue... :-)

Thanks a lot for your patience :-)

comment:
You can just remove quotes in your query:
```sql
WHERE name LIKE ${Name}%
   and surname LIKE  ${Surname}%
```
To set some not-null value just specify it with quotes in parameters binding dialog. If you need NULL - leave it empty.

Note: Some databases will fail processing expression 'LIKE NULL'. As they may support only `IS NULL` expression.

documentFactory.setNamespaceAware(namespaceAwarness);
to true, base on the fact registerNs() was invoked or not.

It could look like that:

XMLDocument.of()
  .namespaces().add("m", "http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0")
  .from(ProbaTest.class.getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream("pom.xml"))
  .build()
  .xpath("//m:project/m:scm/m:url/text()")
  .get(0);

  .from(ProbaTest.class.getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream("pom.xml"))
  .build()
  .xpath("//project/scm/url/text()")

comment:
Hi @ioterateam,
you need to disable swipeRefreshLayout until 1first row is fully visible.
1. Extend TableView (MyTableView)
2. add a TouchHandler in MyTableView `TouchHandler mTouchHandler;` + add setter
3. Override  `dispatchTouchEvent(MotionEvent ev)`
4. call `mTouchHandler.onTouchEvent(ev)`
5. in your fragment/activity set your TouchHandler on MyTableView:
`setTouchHandler(this);`
6. implement the touch handler:
`
onTouchEvent(MotionEvent ev) {
mSwipeRefreshLayout.setEnabled(getRowHeaderLayoutManager().findFirstCompletelyVisibleItemPosition() == 0)
}
`

you might want to check if the event is DOWN or MOVE, depending what you achieve.

comment:
Error is `java.lang.NoSuchFieldError: INSTANCE` when calling the toString method of a generated JAXB class, where the error points to the first line of that generated toString method:

```java
final ToStringStrategy2 strategy = JAXBToStringStrategy.INSTANCE;
```

Easiest way I have found to reproduce this is to create one maven project which generates any JAXB class(s) from a schema using the older 0.11.1 jaxb2-basics, including the `-XtoString` arg. Exact setup I used was this:

```xml
<plugin>
    <groupId>org.jvnet.jaxb2.maven2</groupId>
    <artifactId>maven-jaxb2-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>0.13.3</version>
    <executions>
        <execution>
            <goals>
                <goal>generate</goal>
            </goals>
            <configuration>
                <schemaDirectory>${project.build.outputDirectory}</schemaDirectory>
                <bindingDirectory>src/main/xjb</bindingDirectory>
                <args>
                    <arg>-mark-generated</arg>
                    <arg>-XtoString</arg>
                    <arg>-XsimpleEquals</arg>
                    <arg>-XsimpleHashCode</arg>
                    <arg>-Xsetters</arg>
                    <arg>-Xsetters-mode=direct</arg>
                    <arg>-Xcopyable</arg>
                    <arg>-enableIntrospection</arg>
                </args>
                <plugins>
                    <plugin>
                        <groupId>org.jvnet.jaxb2_commons</groupId>
                        <artifactId>jaxb2-basics</artifactId>
                        <version>0.11.1</version>
                    </plugin>
                </plugins>
            </configuration>
        </execution>
    </executions>
</plugin>
```

Then, in a second separate project, include the jar produced from the first project as a dependency, along with jaxb2-basics 0.12.0.  Then create a simple class like this:

```java
public class Junk {
    public static void main(String... args) {
        // MyJaxbClass is any of the classes generated from your other project.
        MyJaxbClass x = new MyJaxbClass();
        // This will throw the NoSuchFieldError at runtime.
        System.out.println(x.toString());
    }
}
```
```
java.lang.NoSuchFieldError: INSTANCE
	at org.mine.MyJaxbClass.toString(MyJaxbClass.java:nnn)
```
caveat: Constructs a NoSuchFieldError with the specified detail message.

comment:
Following the specification -- I don't think there is a defined way to create a key definition such that:

- Some references to that key result in a link + link text, but
- Other references to that key result in only the text

The assumption when creating this mechanism was that if a URI is present on the key definition, it should be used. This has been working for a long time in XHTML / HTML (both `xref` and `ph` result in a link), but PDF was out of sync. 

The only ways I can think of to do this are to have two key definitions (one with `@href`, one without) or to put an ID on the link text, and when you want to reuse that text without a link, refer to it with `@conref` instead of with `@keyref`. I realize neither of those options are really great though (which probably comes from the fact that this use case wasn't previously discussed by the OASIS standards group).

comment:
Although system properties could work for one aspect, I don't think it's a general solution since:

- It requires a global scope and doesn't compartmentalize for reuse (same issue in #516)
- It doesn't handle command context where the value of a variable is relative to the active parent and current command

Ideally there would be a way to register something similar to a `PropertySource` in Spring in a similar fashion to `IFactory`, `IVersionProvider` or `IDefaultValueProvider`. `SystemPropertySource` could be one, `CommandPropertySource` could be another for example.  The basic premise would be to combine all these use cases into the same underlying mechanism.

comment:
I think the question is not so much about namespace handling -- which Jackson does obey, and never produces any non-namespace URI even if default namespace is bound to one -- but API compatibility wrt how to report "empty" or "default" namespace (terminology gets bit ambiguous).
That is just to say that I think XML specification is clear, but question pertains to Java Stax API.

And this is the problem since Stax 1.0 was quite loosely specified (partly covered by Javadocs, some areas seemingly undefined). Worse, Sun/Oracle do not give TCKs for OSS projects except ones under organizations that are JSR/JCP members. So we have not and do not have access to Stax TCK.
JDK internal implementation may have compliant behavior, but I just need to find something somewhere that confirms behavior. One possibility would be later Stax API specification (or even original if there is mention).

Having said all that, you may want to enable

    WastInputProperties.P_RETURN_NULL_FOR_DEFAULT_NAMESPACE

(via `setProperty()` on `WstxInputFactory`, I think?)

since that seems to ... actually be for it.

If and when I have time to work on Woodstox again I should see if we can change the default.
By javadoc looks like it should already have been changed...

1. shouty type names go completely against out coding standard, and, more importantly
2. you would never want to interpolate a function reference! (Function references don't have useful `string` representations.)

> There are also two Unicode characters with hyphens but not spaces (`HYPHEN-MINUS` and `RULE-DELAYED`), which form valid (though nonsensical) subtraction expressions.

"Valid" in what sense? The `-` operator certainly doesn't accept function references, so they're definitely *not* "valid" in the sense of being something that could potentially be accepted by the typechecker.

comment:
It is tempting to choose `new «object» as «name»` for `Action.createWithName`, but in this case we would violate our policy of keeping the two language variants as close as possible. On the other hand, using `new` from Java is very convenient and intuitive.

I think the core of this problem is the unfortunate redundancy caused by `Action.create` and Java's `new` in JtxtUML. Dropping one for the other might work. Personally, I like `new` more than `create`, because the declarative nature of the former seems to fit better into contexts they're usually used in. Not to mention that disallowing `new` would likely be really annoying for users.

I understand that despite all this, the corresponding UML action is still called `CreateObjectAction`. The question is that between UML and Java, where do we want to position our language? Create instead of `new` might be too alienating. But what if we drop `Action.create`, rename `Action.createWithName` to `Action.newAs` or `Action.newWithName`, and in X we support `new` with an optional `as` clause only? At first glance, `Action.new...` looks strange, maybe right because the `Action` prefix implies something imperative.

Of course we could also keep `new`, `Action.create`, `Action.createWithName` in J and support `new`, `new ... as ...`, `create` and `create ... as ...` in X. Apart from the inherent redundancy and the additional inconsistency that `new ... as ...` would be translated to `Action.create...`, the contrast between `as` and `with name` is also confusing. Add to the mix that `as` is also used for casting in X.

Overall, this is a mess I strongly believe we should address. @kovacsgabor, what do you think?

into

```
- Aggregation (FINAL, STREAMING)
```

comment: Looks good to me; I would probably extract the explicit offset `OffsetDateTime.ofInstant(zoneToOffsetConversionInstant, zone).getOffset()` rather than pass it as a "reference instant", but that's merely my preference.
caveat: localDateTime the local date-time to query, not null, but null may be ignored if the rules have a single offset for all instants
label: non-relevant

comment: `SphericalPolygonSet.projectToBoundary(point).getOffset()` seems to compute the offset from the center-line of the boundary and could be used to implement round corners.
caveat: localDateTime the local date-time to query, not null, but null may be ignored if the rules have a single offset for all instants
label: non-relevant

comment:
Also, it returns a stream starting with the first item even if it would be asked to return a stream starting with item n.

So in summary, the problem is because the implementation doesn't take `query.getOffset()` and `query.getLimit()` into account.
caveat: localDateTime the local date-time to query, not null, but null may be ignored if the rules have a single offset for all instants
label: non-relevant

comment:
This is caused by https://github.com/OpenFeign/feign/blame/master/core/src/main/java/feign/Client.java#L85...  Setting `allowUserInteraction` to false immediately closes the stream and causes `getErrorStream`.

See also: https://stackoverflow.com/a/44423631/8651856
caveat: the input stream connected to the error output of the process
label: non-relevant

comment:
With your client.txt renamed to client.prefs I could reproduce the exception, but before I had to remove the Windows paths from the file. They caused another Exception crashing the client on startup because I am on Linux. Important part of the stacktrace:
`Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException: null
	at java.nio.file.Files.provider(Files.java:97) ~[na:1.8.0_171]
	at java.nio.file.Files.createDirectory(Files.java:674) ~[na:1.8.0_171]
	at java.nio.file.Files.createAndCheckIsDirectory(Files.java:781) ~[na:1.8.0_171]
	at java.nio.file.Files.createDirectories(Files.java:727) ~[na:1.8.0_171]
	at com.faforever.client.preferences.PreferencesService.postConstruct(PreferencesService.java:124) ~[bin/:na]`

Furthermore I could crash the client on startup by:
- Creating an empty client.prefs. File is deleted and recreated by the client on next startup, so not a real problem.
- Putting invalid json into client.prefs. This is also not a real problem because it shouldn't happen except if some json library bug is hit. File stays and isn't corrected by the client.

label: non-relevant

comment:
It looks like this is a regression introduced in #859. In particular, some entities (which?) have their `isEftAccepted` field set to `null` (when?), which leads to a null pointer error evaluating it.

This might be as simple as changing the call to `Boolean.TRUE.equals`, but first I'll add some unit tests to reproduce this problem and make sure we don't have any further regressions around it.
caveat: To be equivalent, all of the following conditions must be true: object is not null.
label: non-relevant

comment:
@iliassk One other thing to note is that exclusion of "default" values should allow this, as long as POJO implements `equals()` properly: if POJO was `NON_DEFAULT` class annotation, then POJO-valued properties are checked same as everything else: an instance is constructed using 0-argument constructor, and this instance is compared to (non-null) value, and value is excluded if they equal.

There is also the newish option of "custom" filter for `@JsonInclude`, see:

https://medium.com/@cowtowncoder/jackson-2-9-features-b2a19029e9ff

which does allow any kind of logic you want.

There are no current plans aside from these options however: amount of work involved in implementing various strategies is practically unlimited so I'd prefer to cap it by allowing extension by others at this point.
But I am always open to suggestions on possible techniques for new features.
caveat: To be equivalent, all of the following conditions must be true: object is not null.
label: non-relevant

comment:
should look like this 
searchguard:
  dynamic:
    authc:
      clientcert_auth_domain:
        http_enabled: true
        order: 1
        http_authenticator:
          type: clientcert
          config:
            username_attribute: cn #optional, if omitted DN becomes username
          challenge: false
        authentication_backend:
          type: noop
Using curl with the admin certificate makes not much sense because all authentication and authorization will be bypassed. If you need configuration support pls refer to https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/search-guard for community help.
caveat: If no Authenticator was set in the client's builder, then the Optional is empty.
label: non-relevant

comment:
**Original cause** is that 
`com.sforce.ws.ConnectorConfig.setProxyUsername(String)`
is never called and
`org.mule.modules.salesforce.config.AbstractConfig.initConnectionConfig(ConnectorConfig)`
faulty sets the credentials to Authenticator than to 
`com.sforce.ws.ConnectorConfig`

**Fixable** via setting setProxyUsername and getProxyPassword together with setProxy in ConnectorConfig then Proxy-Authorization header will be set correctly in 
`com.sforce.ws.transport.JdkHttpTransport.createConnection(ConnectorConfig, URL, HashMap<String, String>, boolean)
`
caveat: If no Authenticator was set in the client's builder, then the Optional is empty.
label: non-relevant

caveat: If no Authenticator was set in the client's builder, then the Optional is empty.

comment:
On your elasticsearch committer, have you tried setting ``<fixBadIds>true</fixBadIds>`` (available since Committer version 4.1.0)?

It will truncate what will go in Elasticsearch ID field and append a hash code to keep it unique, but you can store/copy your intact URL in another field beforehand (e.g. with ``CopyTagger`` of the Importer module).

If you really want to eliminate them, you can look at using a ``RegexReferenceFilter`` and filter out long URL with a regex like this (untested):

```
^.{512,}$
```
caveat: In either case, if this channel's file position is greater than the given size then it is set to that size.

comment:
> As far as I know there is no way to join the thread/promise after it was canceled (as .get() and .join() of course always return that the promise was canceled). I wrote a wrapper around the Promise with CountdownLatch (for termination) and AtomicBoolean (for starting) to be able to (almost) await() the termination of the code inside the promise, but maybe you know a better way?

Could you elaborate more? After `Promise` is cancelled you can `get` / `join` it, though you must handle an exception. `CompletionStage.exceptionally` provides an option to convert an exception to some result... So it's a bit unclear what option you  are missing...

comment: Skyframe returns the old FileArtifactValue if the new value is equal to the old one, and I didn't update equals to also cover the ctime. So if the ctime changes but the digest is the same (e.g., on an action cache hit), then the SpawnActionRunner thinks the file was modified underneath.

comment:
How about changing `CompletableFuture<Boolean> ThrottlingStrategy.accept -> boolean ThrottlingStrategy.accept`?

Practically speaking, in `RateLimitingThrottlingStrategy` its calling `RateLimiter.tryAcquire` which internally has a mutex lock here: https://github.com/google/guava/blob/master/guava/src/com/google/common/util/concurrent/RateLimiter.java#L348

I can't imagine similar strategies won't have the same type of penalty. So I don't see the value in having this op be asynchronous.

comment:
Behavior is the same for "Print Image" as "Print PDF" using the Boca driver and "P1 - Rotate 180"

The print job does not get rotated to the other physical limit of the printable area.

HTML, on the other hand, uses the "P1 - Rotate 180" and performs as expected - the print job gets rotated to the other physical limit of the printable area.
